Sir-

I was informed today by Mr Smith, school teacher (Oka Country Indian School) that the pipes connected with the sink were leaking very much, the water running through the floor into the cellar.

I sent a plumber, Mr Jos Lauzon, to repair this leakage immediately.

Will you please advise me, if in such cases I have to wait for an authorization of this Department before ordering the repairs to be done.

Your servant,

Fr. Brisebois
Indian Agent
Oka, P.Q.

T.R.L. MacInnes
Acting Secretary
Ottawa, February 9th, 1932.

Sir,-

I have your letter of the 4th instant, regarding the repairs which you authorized be made to the pipes connected with the sink at the Oka Country Indian Day School. In this connection, I have to say that the action taken by you is approved as these repairs were in the nature of an emergency. In future, however, I have to request that, before incurring any expenditure, you will obtain the authority of the Department. You should report to the Department all matters regarding repairs, etc., stating fully what is required and the approximate cost of same and receive authority before undertaking the work.

After the repairs have been made to the pipes, you should forward an account in duplicate on the form provided for that purpose, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

François Brisbois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

March 15, 1932

Sir,

Mr. Smith, schoolteacher, Oka Indian School, is requesting for the following articles, for his school and residence.

Residence:
- 2 gallons of varnish for the walls
- 4 pints " paint " for stairs & kitchen
- 1 grey & 1 white

School:
- 1 mop
- 1 scrubbing brush
- 1 large glass lamp & 17 for storeroom
- 3 sets of drinking cups

Mr. Smith complains that the water is running from the outside through the cellar, and claims an outlet is needed. He also wants to know if the Department is prepared to grant his request for a garage, claiming he has to rent one for his car.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Pre. Prisebois
Acting Indian Agent
Oka.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 18, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Oka Country Indian Day School to be supplied with varnish, paint and supplies for the school, also for the erection of a garage.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase from a firm on the list to receive consideration, in accordance with departmental instructions, of the following supplies: 3 gallons varnish; 2 pints paint, (1 grey, 1 white); 1 mop; 1 scrubbing brush; 3 dozen enamelware drinking cups and saucers; 100 study desks. It is to be understood that the teacher will carry out the varnishing and painting without cost to the Department. After the purchase has been made, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Relative to the teacher's request for the erection of a garage, I have to say that we have no funds at the present time to provide the cost of having this work carried out.

Relative to the suggestion of the teacher that an outlet be made to carry off the water that is seeping into the cellar from the outside, I have to request that you will state what arrangement you would recommend be carried out to provide a proper outlet to drain the cellar. You should give full particulars as to the work involved and the approximate cost of same. When the Department has this information, consideration will be given to authorizing having the work carried out.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Francois Brisebois, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Oka, P.Q.

Form No. 101
Referring to your letter of the 16th of March, about the suggestion of the teacher that an outlet be made to carry off the water in the cellar of the Oka Indian Country Day School and asking for full particulars as to the work involved and the cost of same., I beg to say that there are two ways to repair the cellar.

First; to fix a pipe from the cellar to a well located at the back of the school (a distance of 140 feet) this would require the digging of a trench of 3 feet deep and to break the cement of the cellar's floor to fix the pipe., the cost of this work would amount to $115.00.

The second proposition, which is the best but more expensive., would be to have the inside of the cellar recanted with waterproof cement,, this would cost around $300.00.

In the first proposition the water would come through the cellar and leave by the outlet,, while in the second there would not be any water coming in.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Acting Indian Agent

Oka.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Sir:

Referring to my letter of May the 14th, relative to the repairing of the cellar of the Oka Indian Country Day School, I beg to say that there was an error in the estimation of the cost of the work for having the cellar recoated with waterproof cement.

Marinier Brothers, Contractors, would undertake this job that is to say, to put a 4 inches coat of armed waterproof cement on the floor and on the walls of the cellar for $175.00, they would employ Indians only at this job under their supervision.

This job would be guaranteed.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Pre Brissola
Acting Indian Agent
Oka.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, May 26, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letters of the 14th and 21st instant, with reference to draining the cellar of the Oka Country Indian Day School. The Department is not prepared to consider water-proofing the basement but is interested in the possibility of draining it satisfactorily. At the time the school was built, there was a drain installed to keep the lot clear of water, and it should be possible to connect up with this at much less expense than a total of $115, which you estimate. Please ascertain who installed this other drain, get a definite idea concerning its location and let me have a further report with estimate.

Your obedient servant,

F. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

F. Brisbois, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Oka, P. Q.
Sir:-

Referring to your letter of May the 26th, relative to the draining of the Oka Country Indian School, I beg to say that I went at the School with the man who has worked there when it was installed and that my last estimation to dig a trench and replace the drain properly is $70.00, providing the tiles pipes are in good order.

At my visit at the School it had not rained for three weeks the soil was very dry everywhere, but the water was still running through the floor and the walls of the cellar, it seems that the ground (which is mostly composed of clay) on which the School is built is waterproof like, and that the drains which are under the floor of the cellar connected with the outlet are useless.

As the children attending School are now away I would kindly ask you to delay for this work until the next visit of your Inspector, because I hesitate to recommend an expense of $70.00 which will not improve the conditions of the cellar of this School.

Your obedient servant

Frs Brisebois
Indian Agent
Oka, P.Q.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Oka, September 23rd, 1932

Sir:

Would you kindly let me know if the Department has decided to have repairs done in connection with the cellar of Oka Indians Country Day School, which as you know is in very bad condition, as the coal for this School will be delivered shortly, and as this coal (7) tons will have to be stored into the cellar I would ask you inform me of your decision about these repairs.

I would also ask you to let me know about the requests made by different Indians of this reserve toward the repairing of houses, barns, etc., whose requests have been looked upon by Mr. Ins T. McGookin at his last visit at Oka in August.

Your obedient servant

Fr. Brisebois
Indian Agent
OKA.

Department of Indian Affairs

He will call at your office.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Form No. 101
Sir:

Referring to the drainage in the Oka Indian Country Day School I must inform you that there is six inches of water in the cellar it will be almost impossible to store the coal there unless you give authorization to buy lumber to replace the actual coal bin which is out of use owing to water and dampness, the lumber required would be for a bin of 6 feet long by 7 feet wide, a little extra lumber would also be required for the floor of the cellar in order that the teacher can have access to the shelves where he stores his provisions for the winter.

Your obedient servant

Fr. Brisebois
Indian Agent
Oka.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA.
Oct. 24, 1932.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 20th with further reference to the drainage in the Oka Indian Country Day School, I beg to say that you may purchase the lumber required to repair the coal bin and a small extra amount for the floor.

With reference to the water in the basement would you kindly obtain and submit to the Department a price for the installation of a drain from the cellar floor and connected to the drain that lies along parallel with the school building, and was installed at the time that the school was built to take away the surface water. This drain empties into the gulley at the rear of the school and I am under the impression that it is deep enough in the ground to provide for drainage in the basement.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Fr. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.
Indian Country School,
Oka, Que.,
October 26, 1932.

To the Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

Regarding the cellar of the residence of the Indian Country Day School which is flooded with water and is very unhealthy to my pupils and family and as I am held responsible for their welfare I shall have to report the situation to the Department of Health.

When Mr. M. Smith was here in August he made a written report but since then nothing has been done.

But coal has been delivered and piled in the yard as we cannot put it into the water in the coal bin. Something will have to be done immediately.

May I ask if you can assist and consider this problem?

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant relative to the request of Mrs. Paul Gabriel for a hot lunch at noon at the Oka Indian Village Day School, owing to the fact that a number of children from the Country are attending this School.

In reply I beg to advise you that 12 children in school age from the country are supposed to attend the Village School this year, but out of this number only four are attending regularly since the beginning of School in September. It is not well understood why Mrs. Paul Gabriel requested a hot lunch for her children at School as they are the most irregular in attendance at the Village school. Last winter none of her four children went to school according to the teacher, and at present only one of this family is attending. The children from the Country attending the Village school are very irregular in attendance and I would not recommend any expenses for a hot lunch.

According to the teacher Mrs. Tupper the giving of soup at the School by the Department is a waste of money. When a hot lunch was served at this School the Department was paying $15.00 a month for five months a total of $75.00, this amount was paid to feed an average of three or four children from the country every day. When this hot lunch was discontinued last year, the Indian parents did not request same and this year apart of Mrs. Gabriel I have not had any request for the lunch.

Instead of paying for a hot lunch I would rather recommend to supply the few pupils from the Country attending the Village School with a "Thermos bottle" this arrangement would avoid any waste of food, and the parents who really want their children to have soup would supply same themselves when their respective children would be going to School. It would also cost less than the price of a lunch during the whole winter.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

May I ask why there is a shortage of coal delivered to this school this year? By my computation there is approximately a half a ton of a shortage. I cannot do with any less than seven tons.

Will you please communicate with the department and ascertain whether they intend to continue the supplying of soup to the school children this year from December 1st. to March 31st.? And if this is the case, will Mrs. Smith serve it as in former years?

Will you also ask if we are to get the usual treat of candy for the pupils of this and the village school?

I am obliged to requisition the Department for the following:

Laundry soap to the value of 25 cents. (Janitor work)
1 cake of Bon Ami. (For cleaning windows)
Toilet soap to the value of 25 cents.
4 yds. cheap roller towelling.
1 Floor mop.
1 Small bottle of O Cedar polish for dusting school desks.
1 Stove shaker to fit Legare's Jewel heater.

The school clock is broken; I believe it is the spring, as it seemed to uncoil when I was winding it one day last week. Will you see about getting it mended and at your earliest convenience will you get me a time-piece of some sort as I have no watch and we have to use the kitchen clock which makes it very inconvenient.
Will you also arrange to have the school water-tank mended if it is at all possible? Every time the inspector comes he complains of the open drinking water container. It has been out of order now for nearly two years and I am of the opinion that it can be mended if taken to a competent person.

I should like it very much if you would write also regarding the supplying of coal oil to this school residence this year. Please make it clear that the bill last year which seemed exorbitant was really for two months supply of oil. When other residences are lighted I do not see why this one is not.

You will also inform the Department that from now on I will not be held responsible for any damage to the school desks and walls as long as religious meetings are conducted in the class-room. I have tried hard to make the people see that they must not scratch the desks or write on the walls, but it continues and I am at a loss to know what to do further regarding these defacements.

All of the above is very respectfully submitted and I ask for the co-operation of yourself and the Department at the earliest possible date.

Yours respectfully,

Albert E. Smith

Mr. F. Brisbois:

I wish you would ask the department if I may have 5 links of stove pipe. The school is too cold this year and I intend taking the stove out of the dining room in the residence and setting it up in the school. On a very cold day such as we had last week I find it impossible to keep the school warm enough for the pupils or myself to keep warm enough for good work. The residence is so cold that we are going to close the living room and use only the kitchen and dining-room which can both be heated by the kitchen stove.

The first winter we were here we found the place quite warm but last winter it was pretty cold and this winter it is worse. It would seem as if the building had been built of green lumber and it shrinks as it dries thereby making cracks between the boards.

I shall need a new ash sifter. The one I have was worn out last year and I thought I could patch it up to do the year, but it is going fast so I shall have to have a new one. I also need a mop.

Sir,

Reference your letter to me dated Sept. 19 # 20-1-5.
Regarding estimate of the cost of construction of a wood-
shed at the school here.

I have given this my spare time and thought
and have arrived at the following conclusion; After asking
the price of lumber from Mr. Marinier of Oka who is on the
approved list I find that his price is prohibitive and that
we could not erect even a very small shed of rough lumber
for $60, if we were to buy the lumber from him. I have been
to visit several mills not on the list and find that the
one situated at St. Andrews East has the best grade of
lumber and at the same time the cheapest $24.50 per M. This
is the price delivered here. Planed spruce is $31 per M.
May I make a suggestion that the contract be given to an
Indian here, Lindsay Bonspille, who has had experience in
building, having helped me erect a summer home at Restoule.
After talking to him in this respect he thinks that it would
be possible for him to get his material from St. Andrews
and put up the building for $60 but only out of rough lumber.
If the Department were prepared to allow an extra $20 making
$80 in all he could put it up using planed spruce.

I am taking the liberty of enclosing a plan
which I have in mind. The plan is not well done as I have
had no experience in blue print work but I hope that I may
make myself understood by it. The size would be 12'x18'.
There is very little use in putting up a shed unless it is
to be used as a garage. I have not got a car but I may have
before I leave, or my successor might have one.
The length would have to be 18' so as to accommodate the new build of cars. On the width 9' would be allowed for the car and 3' for the wood which would be piled along the side. The roof would be flat and sloping with sufficient slope to allow for drainage of water. A slide window in the back and a small door in the side besides the two large doors in the front.

The following is a list of the required materials with the approximate cost of same:

| 2 small windows @ $2.40               | $ 4.80 |
| 35 lbs. nails @ 5¢                   | $ 1.75 |

$50.20

This, you see, would allow the man $9.80 for his labour in putting it up. This is figured on the basis of a shed 12'x18' of rough lumber only. The estimates and drawings have been done to the best of my ability. If I have been of any service to you in this respect I am very thankful to have been offered the privilege of doing. It has been one way in which I can thank the Department for the many favours conferred in the past.

Sir,

On Sept. 2nd, I asked Mr. Brisbois, the agent, for a broom, a boiler, wash tub, wash board, and a bread box. An indian asked him a few days later for the job of painting the woodshed. Brisbois called today and brought a broom, and said that you had not mentioned anything about the other articles on my requisition. He also brought a gallon of white paint and part of a two quart can of green paint which was left from painting the village school this summer. He said that you had said that I was to paint the wood-shed myself. I doubt that very much. In the first place I was hired here as teacher and not as painter. Secondly it puts me in a bad light with the indians as they will think that I am being paid for it when some of them should have the job. Thirdly, there are very few people who work for the government for nothing. I would advise that the work be given to one of the indians; four dollars I think should be ample. Regarding the articles mentioned they were here when we came but the bread box got so rusty that we had to discard it. The painters stood on the boiler to paint the school two years ago. The wash tub and board just plain wore out. May we not have them replaced?

While we are at it, may I know why it was that we were not given new pipes for the school last winter. I can show you stove pipes we used last winter that had holes in them as large as quarters. I asked twice for them but funds were too low. The insurance company would not care about such evidence were it presented in case of the place being damaged by fire. May I ask also why the supply of kerosene has been cut off. When I came here in 1930 Mr. Ferrier told me that the Dept. supplied lamps and oil. Two years ago it was cut off. That is quite all right providing the payment of lights is curtailed in other schools and residences. But it is still being paid for other schools and teachers. It seems a little unfair.

Please pardon me for writing this letter direct to you but I can do nothing else. I have proof for all these statements and am willing to furnish it when needed. I do not blame you for the above. You and Mr. McGookin have been very nice about anything I have asked for in the past, and I thank you both for it.

Yours truly,

The Country Day School,
Oka, Que., Sept. 17, 1936.

Mr. F. Harbour,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

Dear Sir,

I should like to know if you have made any further arrangements regarding the installation of a furnace in the school and residence here.

You will remember that, at the time of the visit of Mr. Thibault in May, we discussed with him the advisability of putting a stove in the basement and decided that the fire hazard would be too great. I understood then that the matter would be taken up at Ottawa and that steps would be taken to have a furnace installed which would heat both school and residence.

A furnace to supply the required number of units of heat for the cubic footage of this whole building should not cost very much. There is a place in the basement for a furnace with smoke and heat pipe holes already arranged.

If a furnace is not installed there will most certainly have to be a stove set in the basement to warm the floors. This would be a waste of time and money because there will have to be a furnace installed eventually. If the furnace is not put in we will have to have new lining for the both stoves in the school and for one in the residence. There will also be 20 new pipes bought to replace the ones which are now too old to do further duty. The saving on coal I believe would pay for the furnace in a few years. I would be willing to give any labour I could to help with the installation of the outfit. I am always willing to help in any way so as to save on the cost of any repairs here.
Last winter we had two stoves going in the school and two in the residence and then we could not warm the floors. There seems always to be about a foot of cold air on the floors. Every winter we have to close school a few days owing to the cold; I teach on Saturdays to make up lost time but I do not feel like continuing this plan since the place could be warmed by a furnace.

When I took charge of this school eight years ago I was assured that, the place being new, it would always be warm. From our first winter here we have found it to be anything else but warm and it gets worse from year to year. We have a four months old baby this year and she will have to be on the floor for a part of each day. I do not see how we can warm the floors if there is no other way of heating the residence than the method now employed.

You would be doing the pupils, my family and me a great favour if you would take this matter up with the proper persons at Ottawa and give me their decision in the very near future.

Thanking you for all past favours, I am,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Teacher-in-charge.

Oka, November 23rd, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th instant regarding the furnace to be supplied at the Oka Country Indian day school.

In reply I beg to say that it is only this morning that I could get an expert from a company to come and see the school house and give me an estimate of the installation of a furnace in this school.

The Legare Company of Montreal could install a furnace of 25 to 3500 cubic feet for the price of $349.25; it would be a furnace "EGLAT" with the fire box built of Boiler Plate, welded and riveted; the cost of the furnace itself, installed would be $325.00 but in order to send the heat in the class room there would be an extra expenditure of $24.25.

This price comprises the whole outfit installed and guaranteed to give 70 degrees of heat Fahrenheit.

The company guarantees to install the whole thing in 48 hours after the reception of the order. I would recommend such installation because the school house is really cold.

The kitchen stove of this school would also need new fire box and lining; the price would be $13.40 and if the furnace is purchased, the replacing of the stove linings would be free of charge; that is to say the handwork.

Kindly let me have your immediate answer because the roads from Montreal to Oka may close at any day thus delaying the installation of the furnace.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Francois Harbour,
Federal Agent for the
Oka Indian Reserve,
OKA.

Dear Sir:

I am reporting on unsanitary conditions existing in both Country and Village Indian Schools. In the Country School, the outside privies are repulsing and the adjoining lot is used as a dumping ground. In the village, the privies outside are also in a very bad condition. I cannot see the reason why these children are not given modern facilities by adopting for these schools inside chemical toilets. And surely cleanliness should be strictly in force in these establishments.

The Law and our Provincial Rules demand that no child should be admitted in school if not vaccinated against smallpox. Out of 66 pupils only one is vaccinated. It is my duty to ask you to see that vaccination will be made in a very near future. I will make a control visit in eight days, after which the person in charge of the schools shall refuse to admit any child not vaccinated.

Very truly yours,

P.S. A copy of this letter is sent to Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare and Training, Ottawa.

(Sgd.) Dr. Jean L. Faillé, D.P.H.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

The Department is just in receipt of a copy of a letter dated the 12th instant from Dr. Jean Louis Faillé, D.H.F. The first paragraph of this letter reads as follows:

"I am reporting on unsanitary conditions existing in both Country and Village Indian Schools. In the Country School, the outside privies are repulsing and the adjoining lot is used as a dumping ground. In the village, the privies outside are also in a very bad condition. I cannot see the reason why these children are not given modern facilities by adopting for these schools inside chemical toilets. And surely cleanliness should be strictly in force in these establishments."

Please make immediate arrangements for cleaning the toilets at both the Oka Village and Oka Country schools.

It is difficult to understand why you have permitted conditions to become such that Dr. Faillé finds it necessary to make the report shown above, especially in view of the very large number who are on relief in the Oka Agency. There is no reason why work of the nature required should not be done by those on relief.

The Department will expect to hear from you within a week that the conditions about which Dr. Faillé complains have been fully rectified.

Yours truly,

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Preservitt is much superior to ordinary shingle stain. It gives a solid colour coat to shingles and at the same time penetrates and ensures long wear and prevents warping.

Preservitt is ready for use, but if necessary can be reduced with linseed oil.

**New Shingles**—One coat brushed or dipped will give good results. When dipped stand shingles on end to permit surplus to drain off.

**Old Shingles**—One brush coat freely applied will in most cases be sufficient.

One gallon of Preservitt dipped will cover approximately 500 shingles one coat. One gallon brushed will cover approximately 300 square feet, one coat.

**Garages, Barns, Fences**—Two coats are recommended for a permanent coating and a fine finish.

**Exterior Woodwork, Composition Roofing, Metal Surfaces, etc.**—One or two coats, without thinner.
Quebec
July 3, 1939

Attention of R. H. Hoey, Esq.

Dear Sir,

From actual experience and inside information furnished to me by teachers who instruct in schools or who preserve, the school rooms are too dark, especially in the winter time, the following interior treatment is advisable—to have the ceilings and walls washed thoroughly, then rinsed free of all traces of soap. Then one coat of Glidden Base or Priming paint over all; next the ceilings finished in cream or some reflecting color, the walls finished in delicate Green Speedwell Paint, and harmonizing trim. The net result would be a brighter and more livable school room where that was effected.

This is only a suggestion of mine, if interested I am in a position to quote you a fair and equitable price after I would have measured the size of room in question. There is one school with a northerly exposure, the other, westerly, hence suggestion.

Very truly yours,

John J. Angers.
Quebec
July 3rd 1939

C. A. Haig

Dear Sir:

Having received information which I believe correct, with regard to having the two schools on this reserve repainted, I beg to submit the following tender, with specifications as outlined below:

- All knots soaked with turpentine to loosen scaling paint, and to draw the paint scraper and allowed to dry; paid knots to be reshelled.
- All other places also are checked and feeling of scaling to be scraped and wire brushed thoroughly; then repainted with Glidden's Base or Tricking Coat as undercoat. Then one coat of Glidden's Endurance House Paint (price $2.00 per gallon) in desired color, and trim to harmonize, two coats of Glidden's Porch and deck paint on steps and porches.
- Windows to be repainted where necessary.
- All window wash, casing etc. to receive two coats.
of above brand and quality. Our buildings to receive same treatment as main buildings. All material for erecting scaffolds to be supplied by me, with minimum nail holes, and repainted where they necessarily occur.

The paint to be applied evenly and just thin enough to prevent scaling, nothing in the way of linseed oil to be added to the paint and no more than one-half pint of turpentine to each gallon of house paint. Two coats of single stain on roofs. With such treatment, I can safely say that it will not be necessary to repaint within six or seven years.

Price - each school - with above specified one hundred and forty dollars, all paint to be furnished by me, so I am prepared for this district. Will be ready to start after the Oka United church shall have been repainted by me, about July 10th, ready to start with the village school, as my material is right close by, for scaffolds.

Below for your convenience, color chart and card for harmonies.

Very truly yours,

John Anger.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Harbour has advised me to write in to inquire if the Department wish soup to be served, as usual, to the Indian children for noon lunch during the winter months of January, February and March.

Many of the pupils have a long way to walk to school and we noted last winter that many of them only had bread and butter after lunch. Dear Mr. Briebois,

I am sorry I was not here when you called yesterday. Mr. Nicholas told me Tuesday night you were coming but I had no way of letting you know what was going on. It was necessary for me to go to Montreal with my wife & the twins to see the hospital doctor so I got permission from the Dept. to have a holiday.

I am enclosing another requisition. Since you were here Mr. Beatty visited the school and wishes me to get the French texts I have ordered. The present book we are using he said was too difficult, so advised me to order the Elson Basic Reader.

We asked for an indoor toilet before but thought the Dept. understood we wanted 2 with septic tanks for the use of the children so we are enclosing a cut of what we want and stating what is for use in the residence.

I forgot the typewriter. I would like to have one as I do a lot of business correspondence and would find it very useful. The other articles we found we needed after your visit.

I trust the Dept. will not think we send our requisitions too frequently as this should be for the year 1941. Yours Truly,

Dear Sirs:

I beg to submit the following tender for the contract of painting the Oka Country Indian Day School.

Measurements are as follows:
- Two thousand and one hundred and thirty-five square feet of roof surfaces, school and residence.
- Twenty-three square feet in single stain.
- Two thousand five hundred and twenty square feet of walls and ceilings, interior surfaces, including entryways, all openings deducted, i.e., all pane surfaces, in school rooms proper.
- One thousand seven hundred square feet, exterior surfaces of walls on school proper, all glass pane areas deducted, but porticos, steps, cupola, and caves included.
- Three hundred and twenty square feet of exterior wall surfaces of Kitchen, attached to residence of country school.
- Five hundred and ninety-seven square feet of painting surface on exterior of teachers' residence; leaves and trim allowed, openings deducted.
- Total of six hundred square feet painting surface on tent buildings, wood shed and two closets.

Specifications:
All surfaces to be painted will be undertaken on the basis of two coats, including trim windows, double windows and doors.
Roofs to be painted in Blue Shingle.

All outside surfaces to be painted with pure exterior paint, suitably thinned with double boiled linseed oil, on first coat, and finish coat as it comes from the can, either Sherwin-Williams, Glidden, Japco, etc., Martin, Seneca or Lowe Ohio Paints to be used at the choice of the buyer.

Suggested treatment of walls and ceilings, interior - ceiling in white or light gray, walls in light gray or Nile green. Foundation coat light gray to hide inequalities of grain of B.C. fir, etc.

Cher Monsieur,

Les rapports des visites faites à nos écoles, durant l'année scolaire 1943-44, par notre Inspecteur, le Dr. Jean Paquin, M.V., indiquent que les conditions sanitaires sont en général assez bonnes. Cependant les améliorations suivantes s'imposent:

**Écoles Indiennes:**
Les latrines hydroseptiques devraient être installées dans les deux écoles.

L'intérieur des deux écoles devrait être peinturé en blanc.

Nous nous permettons aussi de vous rappeler les recommandations suivantes:

**Éclairage:**
Les élèves devront être placés de manière que la plus grande quantité de lumière leur arrive latéralement et à gauche. Ils ne devront jamais recevoir la lumière en face.

**Vestiaires:**
Un vestiaire séparé et ventilé devrait être aménagé et contenir un nombre suffisant de crochets dans chaque école.

**Balayage et lavage:**
Le balayage humide quotidien de même que le lavage mensuel des planchers sont obligatoires.

**Fuites:**
Les puits devraient être de bonne construction et bien protégés. Durant la semaine qui précèdera la rentrée des classes, ils devraient être désinfectés et pompés suffisamment.

Nous vous remercions de la bonne coopération que vous démontrez, et nous vous prions de nous écouter.

Votre tout dévoué,

Léonard Milot, M.D.,
Officier Médical.

LM/MFG

Président de la Commission Scolaire,
Ministère de la Santé,
Département de l'Instruction Publique.
St. Eustache, July 5, 1944.

Mr. François Brisebois etc.

Dear Sir,

The reports on visits made in the schools during the school year 1943-1944 by our inspector, Dr. Jean Paquin, M.V., show that sanitary conditions are generally good. However, the following improvements are necessary.

Indian schools: The hydroseptic latrines should be installed in both schools. The interior of both schools should be painted white. We also beg to remind you of the following recommendations:

Lighting: The pupils should be placed in such a way as to receive from the left side the greatest quantity of light. They should never receive such light from in front.

Cloakrooms: A separate ventilated cloakroom should be provided in each school and contain a sufficient number of coat-hooks.

Sweeping and washing: The daily wet sweeping and the monthly washing of floors are compulsory.

Wells: The wells should be of good construction and well protected. In the week preceding the reopening of classes, they should be sufficiently disinfected and flushed.

We thank you for your cooperation ...

(Sgd) Léonard Milot, M.D.,
Medical Officer.

Dear Sir:

Would you kindly refer the matter of providing hot soup for the children in the school through the winter months to Oliver for a decision by the officials of the School Branch of Indian Affairs?

I believe it would help in sustaining attendance through cold weather, when attendance usually tends to fall off.

I bought a canning machine this summer with which I used to can tomatoes for myself and neighbors, (387 cans altogether) and I have some dozens of cans which may also be used in the same. Incidentally, I plan, if all goes well, to extend our activities in this little next summer.

At my last visit at Oka at the beginning of this week, Mrs. Sloan, teacher at Oka Village School, complained that the roof of the School was leaking. An examination of the roof revealed that it leaked at two different places and a carpenter was requested to make an estimate for the work and material needed to repair the roof.

This was estimated to cost about $8.00 or $9.00 at the most, labour and materials.

While at the School Mrs. Sloan requested me to apply to have a small window cut on the side of the building, in the toilet and bathroom, as when this was installed no provision for an air outlet nor window was made. This window would provide light in that room and at the same time would air the premises. This work is estimated to be of about $15.00 completed.

The teacher also pointed out that there are no lights in the back of the residence nor in the wood shed, which is located, about 35 feet from the building, this she claims is needed as she often have to go to this shed for her fuel etc., at night when alone with her two children. Although I could not obtain a price for this work from an electrician it is believed that to install a light on the veranda and in the shed would not be expensive.

Kindly let me know if the above requests will be granted. I wish to say that instructions have, however, be given for the patching of the roof in order to prevent deterioration of the building.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 19, 1945.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, the Department approves the expenditure of approximately $9.00 for repairing the roof at the Oka Village School.

It is noted that you recommend an expenditure of $15.00 for cutting a small window in one side of the building and that you also recommend the installation of a light on the verandah and in the wood-shed. Both these recommendations are approved, and you may arrange to have them done.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Oka Country Day School.

Gentlemen:—

We have had a request from your Mr. F. Brisebois, agent at Coughnawaga, P.Q., for an estimate for insulation for the school houses located at Oka, P.Q., and on the Oka - St. Placide Road, P.Q.

Will you please sign white and blue copies of contract at the lower left hand corner, retaining the yellow copy for your records, and return the two copies to us with your official order.

This work could be done two or three weeks after we have received your order.

If there is further information you desire, please advise,

Yours very truly,

Canadian Johns-Manville Co. Limited.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.,

We have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to insulating the Oka Country and Oka Village Indian Day School.

In view of the lack of funds, we are unable to provide the amount required at the present time. You might bring the matter to our attention early next May.

Bernard F. Neary,

PP/EM.
The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant relative to the insulating of the Oka Indian Schools, in which you advise that owing to the lack of funds, you are unable to have this work done at present.

As stated in your communication this matter will be brought to your attention early next May.

If sufficient funds had been available it would have been suggested to proceed with the insulation of the Country School first, as this building is located on top of a hill facing the Lake of Two Mountains and therefore exposed to the west wind mostly all the time.

(Frs. Brisebois)

Bernard T. Henry,

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Oka Indian Reserve, Oka Indian Agency, Province of Quebec, Electoral District of Laval-Two Mountains

We have two day schools in the Oka Indian Agency. One of these schools is located in the Village of Oka and the other is located about three miles from the village.

Amongst other things that the teachers have done most faithful work in the year just now closed. It was marked with much success in various ways but especially in the acquisition of the English language which may be taken as the foundation of still greater successes and to which achievements

I believe some measure should now be enacted that would secure a regular attendance at schools. This is a branch of work which I consider vital to the cause of Christianity; since nothing can be so insensibly connected and so absolutely dependent on the education of the people for its progress. Therefore, should be encouraged by such means as will secure attendance thereat.

Various means have been resorted to bring about the desired effect alike on the parents and children but have not been satisfactory.

Inducements of various kinds have
were applied to secure the coveted ends; but found the method too expensive for the means at our disposal.

The examination, so conducted at the closing service, is a new feature in these schools, and was very highly commendable. The teachers and the pupils deserve hearty congratulations. The Schools Branch,

Please let me know the salary paid by this Department to the school teachers of the country school at Oka, also what is paid in the village school: I understand that the amount paid in the village is considerably higher than that paid in the country but that the work of each is about the same. MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

Replying to your inquiry of today's date in regard to the Oka schools I beg to say that the Department contributes to the Oka Country School $150.00 and to the Village School $250.00, the Methodist Missionary Society being responsible for the balance of the salary in each case.

The discrepancy in the contributions of the Department may be explained in this way. Up to the year 1909 the salary allowed at each of these schools was only $250.00, one-half of which was paid by the Department and one-half by the church. On July 1, 1909, the salaries were increased to $300.00, one-half to be paid by the Department. On November 30, 1910, in order to retain the services of Mrs. Smith, who is a very competent teacher, at the Village School, the Department increased its contribution to $250.00, making her total salary $400.00. Memorandum:

Mr. MacKenzie,

In reference to Rev. Mr. Arnaud's letter and enclosure attached I beg to make the following comments.

When I was at Oka last year I was informed that there were thirteen children of school age in the village and this number included those of Rev. Mr. Oka's family. There are about eleven Protestant families in the village and about thirty-nine in the country, eight of which might be said to be nearer the village than the present country school. This shows that the great majority of the Indians permanently live in the country while the villagers are comparatively few and migratory and the population is on the decrease yearly as the Indians are going on farms.

With regard to the statement that four children are attending Roman Catholic school. I assume that this has reference to Joseph Cree, who lives among the French farmers some five miles from Oka and whose children are attending the Cote Rouge Public (French) school, which is not half a mile from his place. Last spring he told me that his children were attending this school, but were not being interfered with in their religious beliefs by the priest or any individual in the Township of the District and the teacher in this regard. Knowing the condition of the road between Cote Rouge and Oka, I do not think that Cree's children would ever become regular attendants at a village school if the same were re-opened.

As regards Rev. P. Oka; he is the local missionary to the Indians and native - member of the St. Regis band. He has a family of eight. Being an outsider and whose influence is unknown to the Indians, it is impossible for him to be called upon to distribute the scanty allowance to the dissolute are of the majority of the Indians. In order to give his children the advantages of schooling practically at their own door, he is well equipped to send his children to the country school as he has a team of oxen driving horses. Moreover the change would involve considerable additional expense. The building which is held in view for a school would have to be rented and altered. The item of conveying the country children to the village would be considerably increased as it is likely it will be necessary to provide two riders. The matter of conveying the children to school has been tried at Oka two or three years ago and has proven unsatisfactory. The present officer has complained more than once that few of the country children who live near the school do not attend owing to lack of proper clothing. It would therefore be out of question to expect these and others to go five or six miles to school.
The finding and action of the Commissioners of the Montreal District of the Methodist Church appear to be based on information received from a single and apparently interested source through the present local missionary who has, ever since his return to Canada been agitating for this change. If the Department is disposed to give additional educational advantages to the children of the village, I would suggest that a school be opened as an experiment, and then during the winter months only, Mrs. (Rev.) Macdonald holds a teacher's certificate and could be engaged as a teacher for $25.00 a month and a house could be rented for $4.00 a month. This arrangement might be a little more expensive than engaging a man to drive the children to the country school, but I am of the opinion the results would be more satisfactory.

Chas. Clarke

As Mrs. Oke is a qualified teacher, she is quite competent to look after the education of her own children on any days that they are unable to attend the Country School.

The Department tried the experiment of collecting the children and driving them to school, but it was found to be a failure, and I agree with Mr. Cooke that there is no need for another school on this reserve.

Rev Sir -

I have given consideration to your letter of November 20th, in reference to the representations made to you regarding school facilities on the Oka Reserve.

As you may be aware we conducted a school in the village for sometime, but were forced to close through lack of attendance. The majority of the Protestant children on the reserve reside in the rural district and not in the village. Even there the attendance is very unsatisfactory among those who are within a reasonable distance of the school.

We tried the experiment of conveying the children to the country school, but that proved a failure, and I do not think that we could favourably consider conveying them from the country into the village.

It seems to me that a school must be conducted in the country for the benefit of the Indians now resident there, as well as for those who in the future may wish to leave the village to follow agriculture, as some are now doing. While I sympathize with Mr. Oke's ambition to have his own children educated, I cannot see that the Department should be called upon to establish a second school in the village without reasonable certainty of success, and, from the information I have, any degree of success is highly problematical. In no event could I consider the establishment of a higher grade school where there are no children of the band (Mr. Oke is not a member) to obtain any practical benefit therefrom.

In view of all the circumstances I regret that I cannot see my way clear to make any change at present in the existing arrangement on the reserve.

Sir,

I beg to report that while at Oka, week before last, I inquired into the educational facilities of the Protestant Indian children who live in or near the Oka Village and who do not now attend any school.

There are 13 children of school age in the village and 14 in the country nearby, only 6 of these numbers are in the habit of attending schools while the rest, over 20, have never gone to any. I enclose herewith a list of children living on these sections of the settlement.

The scheme of driving these children to the present Country school, if put in operation, would, in my opinion, not meet the desired end, owing principally to the distance and the widely scattered settlements to be covered, and the antipathy of the parents to the scheme. The cost will be in the neighborhood of $500. Agent Bertrand is prepared to undertake the work for $500 a year (10 months) and provide his own equipment, while A. Howard Oke, an Indian, will do the same for $400.00 a year and the Department to provide the equipment - vehicles, robes, etc., which will at least cost $200.

The only alternative is to re-open a school in the village and I would recommend that this be done. The building formerly used as a school, belonging to Chief J.B. Gaspe, is available and in good condition and

The expenditure incidental on the re-estab-

satisfactory to all parties concerned. The children in

for its efforts and expenditure of means for these people, that I am at times led to the belief that it would be far better to hand the matter of their education over to the provincial authorities. Dear Sir:

Possibly the fact is unknown that Oka is a summer resort and entirely different from rural conditions. The cost of living is very much the same as the city. The consequence is that the teacher is at a greater expense in board, lodging etc., than she would be teaching in a rural community.

The personal appearance as will be seen in a situation like this is an important factor in the success of the work. This is not so prominent in a rural condition. The dress is another factor which all concede as important in the education of people, especially Indians.

I purposely leave unmentioned qualifications which I think will be taken for granted.

In view of this a salary at the rate of six hundred per annum is entirely inadequate. Teachers elsewhere under similar conditions receive nothing less than nine hundred.

I love my work & see satisfactory
result and should be exceedingly sorry if I should be forced by necessity to leave it. I may say the conditions in the Country school is exactly similar.

I trust in view of this the Department will be generous and just in determining the salary.

Sincerely yours,

Helen Earl.

Dear Sir,

I beg to call the attention of the Department of one Ralph Gabrielle who since he came to school in November last has played truant and otherwise committed depredations about the school.

He is absolutely incorrigible. He is the son of Chief Jos. Gabrielle. He came to me with no home training whatever. He has been a problem to me. I have exhausted all means of helping the boy and all my efforts have proved useless.

The outlook for this boy is anything but promising. I am sure if he is not taken in to some Correctional Institution he will prove dangerous, as he shows symptoms of anti-social tendencies. I cannot have him coming to my school for the sake of the other children. His influence over the others is immoral and reactionary.

Can the Department do something for this boy. If placed in a Reformatory just at this time it might prove his salvation.
He would at least be occupied with some constructive program, but home he has nothing to do but loaf and does worse at school. It is impossible to influence the boy through his parents to something better.

After studying his case in his home life and his social environment I have come to the conclusion that he can only be saved by taking him now to a Reformatory of some kind.

I'm quite positive for the sake of the school discipline he should not be allowed to attend. I make this suggestion to the Department because of my interest in the welfare of this boy.

Awaiting an early reply,

I am

your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

A number of children under school age are attending my school. My regular pupils demand all my time and I cannot give these children the proper attention. Before dismissing them I wish to know if there any way of securing a teacher for these little ones.

The other application is from Miss Kathleen F. Armstrong who served as supply teacher for a time at the Mount Elgin Institute. I do not know much about her qualifications other than that she has Normal School training. I am inclined to think that Miss Oke would be the more efficient. Would it not be advisable to give her a trial?

I appreciate the fact that the school opens on the first of September and that action must be taken immediately. Since I came to the office a week ago I have been doing the best I could to secure a teacher for the Oka Village School, but so far have no one to recommend except Miss Oke whom I believe would fill the position more satisfactorily than Miss Armstrong. Sir:

Extract from Inspector Brady's report on the Oka Village School visited on May 13, 1941.

The First Grade pupils present had done not more than white pupils would have covered in one month in Reading. They understand no English when they enter school and the attendance is so irregular that very little progress is made. The upper grades make fair progress, especially in Arithmetic and Spelling. The writing is of rather poor quality and the exercises are carelessly done. Little art is taught and no handwork and no projects are attempted. Singing is not taught, except in preparation for an occasional concert in connection with the Sunday School.

The nine months session is beginning to show an effect on the amount of progress being made, as the attendance has always been low here in the spring months. It would be much better to open at the first of September and close the end of May, as is the custom in this province with the few nine months schools that remain.
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Wilkinson:

In reporting on his recent visit to your school Mr. Doucet intimates that he stressed the practical side of education rather than the strictly academic phase. You are probably aware that Mr. Doucet has had very wide experience as an instructor both in vocational and academic subjects and was, prior to his appointment to this Department, an instructor at the vocational school in Regina.

The Department's aim is to prepare the pupils to cope with the exigencies of life as they are found in the community in which they reside. The school programme, we believe, should begin with social settings that surround the community. Education is really an affair of action and not simply an affair of acquiring ready-made responses through mechanical repetition. We incline to that process of education by means of which meaningful experiences prepare for life.

As a result we are anxious to have manual training wherever possible. We are certain that you will do your best to introduce and encourage this phase of educational effort in your school.

I realize that carrying out our wishes will necessarily involve a considerable departure from the provincial curriculum but our experience in Indian work has proved to our satisfaction that the policy we now suggest is best suited to Indian children.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of July 27th and also Mr. Phelan's personal letter of July 23rd. I am not sure that I quite see the point in Mr. Phelan's letter. I do not want to avoid responsibility, but I seriously question the advisability of this office writing to Mr. Wilkinson to say that his services are no longer required. We appreciate greatly the courtesy which the Department extends to the Church in connection with these Schools, that is, the privilege of nominating teachers, but having made our nomination, I think that the teacher becomes the responsibility of your Department in case you desire to terminate his services. I say this particularly in view of what Mr. Phelan has written concerning Mr. Wilkinson's teaching abilities. Whilst I am aware that Mr. Wilkinson has been active in certain matters, these have not come to me in any official way, and if they had, I am not at all sure that Mr. Wilkinson is not fully justified in taking some interest in this matter although it was settled by the Privy Council some years ago. I am not making any apology for Mr. Wilkinson's language, as reported in the Agent's letter, copy of which you have sent me. The fact is that whilst the Privy Council has given a judgment, I do not think the case of the Oka Indians can be considered absolutely concluded.

However, what I am writing about is to ask whether your Department has notified Mr. Wilkinson that his services are no longer required. In that case we shall give consideration to the making of a nomination. I note the Agent suggests Miss Doris Diabo for this position. I thought she was teaching at Caughnawaga but as I was away from the office for two months last year, it may be that I have not the correct information.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Your reference to myself in your letter of September 6 to Mr. Hoey has been brought to my attention. In this letter you imply that I have been guilty of introducing discords into the harmony of our official relations. As I am most unwilling to lie under such an imputation any longer than necessary I hasten to explain my small part in the matter under review. A little more than a week ago a man phoned me by long distance from Montreal giving the name of Stuart Wilson, and enquiring whether or not the Oka school position had been filled. While he was still on the line I secured the information from Mr. Phelan that the position was still open and passed on the information to Mr. Wilson as he then called himself. It is quite likely, although I am not sure of this, that I told him that if he were interested in the position he had better make application.

The following day an application did come in but to my surprise it was signed by one George Wilkinson. The next day an Indian from Oka phoned me in Mr. George Wilkinson's behalf but could give no explanation of the apparent case of dual personality displayed.

Assuring you of the continuance of my high regard I am,

Yours faithfully,

DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION
QUEBEC

Announcement of the Summer School for Teachers
Macdonald College, 1948.

The seventeenth annual summer school for teachers, under the auspices of the Department of Education, will be held at Macdonald College from Monday, July 5, to Saturday, July 31, inclusive. This summer school is intended for teachers holding elementary and intermediate diplomas valid in the Province of Quebec.

The purpose of this summer school is to enable certificated teachers to supplement their previous training, to become better acquainted with modern educational movements and methods, and to qualify for more advanced diplomas, in accordance with the regulations of the Protestant Committee of the Council of Education.

Elementary and intermediate certificates shall remain interim until the holder thereof shall have taught for two years successfully and shall also have successfully completed one summer session at an approved professional summer school, when the interim certificate shall be exchanged for a permanent diploma.

Advanced elementary diplomas shall be issued to holders of interim elementary certificates or permanent diplomas who have taught successfully for at least two years and have successfully completed two sessions at an approved professional summer school.

Permanent intermediate diplomas shall be issued to holders of interim elementary certificates upon the successful completion of three summer sessions at an approved professional summer school provided, in each case, that the holders have taught successfully for at least two years and have completed the academic requirements for admission to the intermediate class.
Intermediate certificates shall be granted to teachers holding elementary certificates or diplomas provided they pass successfully the senior high school leaving examinations. The senior high school leaving examination may be taken in two sections for this purpose.

Advanced intermediate diplomas shall be issued to holders of permanent intermediate diplomas who shall have taught successfully for two years and completed satisfactorily three sessions, one of which must be a professional summer school, at one or more approved summer schools.

Teachers whose diplomas have lapsed are eligible for attendance at summer school only after receiving special permission from the Director of Protestant Education.

Applicants will be admitted who for some sufficient reason are unable to take the whole course in one year but could take one complete course in two sessions of the summer school. No credit or bonus can, however, be given unless a complete summer school requirement is fulfilled. Applications for admission will be considered from students who wish to take partial courses without regard to credits or bonus.

Each application must be accompanied by a preliminary deposit of $10. Money orders or cheques for this amount, with the bank charge included, must be drawn in favour of the Secretary, Macdonald College.

Candidates will be admitted, subject to available accommodation, in the order of the receipt of their applications, preference being given, if possible, to students who have attended previous summer sessions.

All applications must be made on or before June 19, 1948.

Students who apply for, and receive, admission certificates, but who, for good and sufficient reasons, find themselves unable to attend the summer school, may ask for and obtain a refund of their preliminary deposit at any time up to June 19, 1948. This date for withdrawal is necessary in order to allow vacant accommodation to be made available for other applicants.

I am returning this letter to you, and I wish to inform you, in reply, that I am writing a note to Dr. Manning, of Toronto, who will inform the Rev. Ottawa, Nov. 6, 1923.

Dear Dr. Manning:

I have received a letter from Miss Helen Earl, of the Oka Village School, with reference to her salary. I find that she was granted an increase of $50, making a total of $700 for the 10 teaching months, plus any bonus provided by law, and that your office was not notified. This increase was granted because of certain expenses this teacher has met in fixing up a room for herself over the present school. It is not the Department's intention to pay the bills in connection with her residence expenditures; but, in view of them, we decided to increase her salary $50 as from the first of September last.

Will you please see that Miss Earl receives the balance due her - a total of $10 for the months of September and October. The Rev. Mr. Smith, Chairman of the Montreal District, is paying her at the rate of $65 per month: it should be, of course, $70.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. C. E. Manning, B.A., D.D.,
General Secretary of Home Missions,
Methodist Missionary Society,
Wesley Buildings,
Toronto, Ont.

Nineteen-twenty-three.

Dear Sir;-

Replying to Mr. Perrier's letter of November 6th,

I note what you say about Miss Helen Earl, teacher of
the Oka Village School, being entitled to $70.00 per month, rather than
$65.00 - the amount we have been paying here.

I will notify Mr. Smith, the Chairman of the Dis-
trict, and have her paid accordingly.

I am,

Faithfully yours,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, August 15th, 1928.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the Department is appointing Mrs. Bertha Tupper, who has had twelve years teaching experience and holds a second class professional certificate, as teacher of the Oka Village Indian Day School for the next school year. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

Mrs. Tupper has been requested to take up duties on September 4th next, the date the school re-opens after the present summer holidays. She will notify you upon her arrival at Oka and you should give her every assistance you can in her work at this school. Should she require any classroom supplies, she has been requested to obtain the necessary forms from you and prepare a requisition which you should send to the Department.

Mrs. Tupper will be accompanied by her young son, thirteen years of age, who is to be permitted to attend classes in the school.

You should forward Miss Laura Oke's resignation as requested in our letter of the 10th instant.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

Ottawa, September 23, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is granting permission to Mrs. Bertha Tupper, teacher of the Oka Village Indian Day School, to attend the Teachers' Conference in Lachute on or about the 2nd proximo, also to attend the Provincial Teachers' Convention in Montreal on the 8th, 9th and 10th proximo. The Department is informing Mrs. Tupper accordingly, also that we will reimburse her for the amount of the taxi fare in travelling from Oka to Lachute and return.

Mrs. Tupper has been requested to obtain a receipt, in duplicate, from the taxi driver, and to hand same to you. When you receive this receipt, you should prepare a voucher, in duplicate, certify same, attach the receipt to the voucher and forward to the Department, when a cheque to reimburse Mrs. Tupper will be sent to her.

Your obedient servant,

T. H. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, P.Q.

Sir:

OTTAWA, September 25, 1922.

Sir:

The Department has been renting a house from J. B. Gaspé for school purposes at Oka Village, for which a rental at the rate of $6.00 per month is paid. The rent was paid in full to the end of July, last.

Mr. School Inspector Primeau, who visited the school on the 15th instant, states that there is a family consisting of father, mother and two children, living in the school, and that this is very inconvenient in carrying on the classroom work.

As we are paying rent for this building, I would be pleased if you would enquire under whose authority this family was granted permission to reside in this house. If they are occupying space required for school purposes, they should vacate the premises at once.

We will expect to hear from you regarding this matter at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

L. P. Blanchette, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

G.P.B. Lane, Agent

Ottawa, March 16th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the cupboard required for the use of the Oka Village Indian Day School, and furnishing particulars and the price at which the same can be obtained.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of a cupboard of the dimensions mentioned by you for the use of this school. It will be necessary, however, before making the purchase, to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and the cupboard should be purchased from the firm quoting you the lowest price. If, however, it is intended to have this cupboard made by a carpenter, you may arrange to have the work done, and the price should not exceed the estimate submitted by you, viz: $22.00.

When the cupboard has been delivered at the school, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. If the cupboard is purchased, you should attach to your vouchers a memo showing the names of the firms asked to quote a price and the prices quoted. If, however, this cupboard is built locally, a voucher, in duplicate, in favour of the person doing the work should be forwarded.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Att'n: Mr. Joint

Re: Sir,

Our school teacher in Aka has been the most difficult to find, owing to the fact that there was no property that could be secured for a school site building.

The school work has been carried on in rented buildings for the last fifty years, all of which were unsuitable from the point of view of school architecture.

We have been offered a new building with ample playground in a suitable locality for two thousand nine hundred dollars. The offer
will hold good for several weeks and for that reason I hasten to bring it to the attention of this Department.

The like opportunity has never presented itself in the last fifty years and I share the opinion of all that if possible immediate action should be taken to secure it, otherwise it will be lost forever.

I am of the opinion that the price is fair and would meet all possible development it would also serve at least for this year as school as well as a home for the teacher which has always been one of the difficulties that a teacher has to overcome.

I trust that the Department will give its earliest and most favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Chief Noah Corrinthe

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department will allow a grant of $10 per month, from November to March of the present academic year, for eggs, milk, soup, meat and biscuits, so that Miss Earl, Teacher of the Oka Village Indian Day School, can give a hot meal to those children who carry their lunch to school because of the distance they live from the village. You may allow Miss Earl to purchase the food necessary, and you should instruct the merchant who is given the business to render an account to you at the end of March. You will then certify and submit it to the Department for payment. The amount of $50 should not be exceeded, and the arrangement is for this academic year, only.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

The school stove no. 4 was this afternoon delivered.

I found on inspection that it was entirely too small for the school and moreover it was a stove without grates making it difficult to manage and regulate.

In stating that the stove would be entirely unsatisfactory the agent advises to try it for a month and if found so he will get another.

I do not see the sense of doing business that way. Why not get one immediately big enough that would be satisfactory all around?

It would save the inconvenience of being without a stove for fifteen days which is the time required from the time of ordering until the stove is delivered and it would be in November or perhaps later.

As the coal is not yet delivered I will not have this stove put up.
until I hear from you.

I trust you will give this your immediate attention as already fire is required in the school to be comfortable. It is my opinion that a teacher who has to manage the stove should pick out a stove which would be satisfactory as to size.

Chief Noah Corinthé also the caretaker think the stove entirely inadequate.

Awaiting your immediate answer.

Yours,

Helen Earl

Aka, Que.
Ottawa, October 11th, 1923.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, regarding the stove which has been supplied for the use of the Oka Village Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say we note that this stove is unsatisfactory for the purpose. We are today instructing Mr. Agent Harbour to have it returned to the firm from whom it was obtained and to arrange for the purchase and delivery of another stove that would be suitable to heat the school building. We are also requesting him to take immediate steps to obtain the quantity of coal required for the winter's use, and to consult you as to the type of stove required. We hope that a suitable stove, as well as the coal required, will be delivered at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Helen Earl,
Teacher, Indian Village School,
Oka, Que.
Ottawa, October 11th, 1923.

Sir:

Miss Earl, teacher of the Oka Village Indian Day School, informs the Department that the stove recently supplied is not satisfactory. She states that it is too small for the school, and as it is without grates it is difficult to manage and regulate. As this stove is not satisfactory, you should have it returned before it is used and another stove purchased—one that would be entirely satisfactory to heat the school. The Department will expect you to attend to this matter at once, as the season is getting late and it is now necessary to have heat in the school building. You should consult the teacher as to the type of stove that should be purchased and arrange for the purchase of same. You should also take immediate steps to obtain the quantity of coal required and have it delivered. We will expect to hear that a suitable stove has been purchased, that the stove now on hand has been returned and also that the coal required has been delivered.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, regarding the repairs required to the front and rear steps and the doors of the Village School. In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have these repairs carried out. We note that you estimate the cost of the material and labour to be approximately $20. When the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

I received your telegram yesterday, and I immediately made inquiries about getting a house for school use. After investigations, I found one from Mrs. Mitchell Frett.

Dear Sir:

I find in the new old house school conditions almost intolerable. The children have no playground whatever. They have one common toilet which is tumbling down. The classroom which I am told is rented outright for the year is a common room for all, the water tap being in that room. It can be seen from this that discipline in the class is almost impossible. We are constantly interrupted, moreover we have not sufficient light to make efficient work possible and the floor space...
is entirely inadequate, making seat arrangement entirely out of the question.

The upper part of the house where I'm supposed to make my home is one large room and would be most uncomfortable, besides being cold it is infested with bugs. To make it comfortable would require a considerable outlay of expense.

In view of this I would ask the question, is it not possible even at this time to acquire a house where we could have some semblance of sanitary conditions? I am thoroughly convinced that renting the present building is a mistake and I am positive in my conviction that other buildings more suitable could have been had.

As I am most concerned in a situation
like this I could do no other than to give you
the facts. I and my work would suffer as the
efficiency of the school work and my comfort were
not thought of in renting the present building.
I am
your obedient servant,

Helen Earl

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 6th inst., I beg to report as follows:

I went to the school house this afternoon and after investigations, I must say that there are two toilets on the property, but one of the two is not being used for the present time. It will be ready for use in a couple of weeks. They are old toilets, but as it is just for the year, I would not recommend the building of new ones. Or if you decide to have one built, we could have it strongly built, with a partition one side for boys and one side for girls, and when the new school house will be erected, it could be transported on the new school property.

As to the communication door, it can be locked from the school side, so that the teacher has only to fix a hook and the door is closed.

The report from the teacher about the upstairs being cold and infested with bugs is not of great importance, as far as I am concerned, for I knew by herself that she did not move in the school house yet. Then how can she say that the house is cold? By this time of the year, it is pretty hard to say that a house is cold, as it is not cold outside yet. With reference to the insects, the teacher told me somebody told her there were some. I visited the upstairs and it looks clean, and moreover Mrs. Frett is going to wash it all over these days.

There are two small doors to be fixed to the upstairs rooms, and a water pipe has got to go through a wall. I think you will authorize me to have these small repairs made.
Sir,

As to your last question, I beg to say that I rented the house for one school year, in conformity with your telegram of August the 23rd, which was reading as follows:

RENT BUILDING FOR VILLAGE SCHOOL FOR ONE SCHOOL YEAR.

Now, if you would decide to have a school house built this fall, I beg to say that the Okanogan school commission of Okanagan built one last year for about $4000.00, not more, and it is a very suitable school.

I am positive that a building like this would be in all points the school house required; and it could be made right now and delivered before winter.

If this suggestion suits your convenience, I can have all the details explained to you and from Tuesday next, on your call, I can go to your office and talk the matter over with you.

Hoping this report will receive your approbation, I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

With further reference to your letter of the 17th inst., in regard to the building of a school house this year, I beg to submit the suggestions as follows:

Mr. Dicker has a house built right in front of the lots bought from the Indians for the erection of a school house. He has three lots and a house built on these lots. There is no shed. The partitions of the house would have to be taken from downstairs and fitted up upstairs so as to make the teacher's residence upstairs. Dicker would sell his house and lots for $200, and would take the Department's lots in exchange.

The other suggestion is the building of a school house immediately. Mr. Fraser has built for the Oag School Board a school house with shed attached to it and closets for boys and girls. I am sending you herewith the plan of said school and the modifications Mr. Fraser has given to me. Their price would be $4,200.00.
