Fir 2", posé en dessous des soliveaux, - au-dessus des soliveaux, il y aura un rang d'épinette embouvetée de 1½ épaisseur. Les chevrons seront en 3" x 5" à tous les trois pieds. La couverture sera de un rang de planche brute et un bardage de cèdre 6' clairs. Les divisions seront faites en 2" x 3" et un rang de B.C. Fir de chaque côté. La plate-forme pour le pupitre de la maîtresse, - un escalier, - et une armoire dans l'école seront compris dans les présentes. La cheminée sera double en bonne brique. Il y aura une fausse tête de cheminée pour recevoir le ventilateur que nous nous engageons à poser. L'extérieur de la bâtisse recevra deux couches de peinture de la couleur indiquée, les bardages seront teints après la pose. L'intérieur : les murs, plafonds et plancher recevront une couche d'huile et une couche de vernis.

PEINTURE.—
Il y aura des crochets à linge posés dans le vestibule.

OUVERTURES.
Cette soumission comprend les châssis simples et doubles, deux lucarnes avec châssis doubles et simples, ainsi que les portes intérieures et extérieures, le tout tel que spécifié sur le plan. Les châssis seront vitrés.

REMISE
Nous nous engageons également par les présentes, à construire une remise à bois et charbon, de 12' x 12' et une closet avec compartiment séparés pour filles et garçons, de plus un urinoir pour garçons.

CLOSETS
Le hangar sera construit en 2 x 4 et un rang de bois embouvé de 1 pouce, la couverture, comme la bâtisse principale, bois et bardaoux.

Les closets seront construits des mêmes matériaux que le hangar et pourvus de ventilateurs.

Cette bâtisse aura donc tel que le plan, 30' x 32', et contiendra une salle d'école et une résidence pour la maîtresse.

Les portes extérieures auront 1" et les portes intérieures auront 1" et seront en B.C.Fir.

Les travaux pourront être terminés pour le 1er janvier 1925.

Fait à Oka, ce 24 septembre 1924.

Sir:

I have the communication which you forwarded from Miss Earl requesting a grant to purchase prizes for the pupils of the Oka Village Indian Day School to be awarded before the school closes for the coming summer holidays.

In connection with grants for prizes, I have to inform you that the practice of the Department is to allow a grant either before the midsummer holidays or at Christmas at the option of the teacher. We can, however, only provide this grant once each year. The schools on the Oka Reserve were allowed a grant of $8 each for prizes to be distributed before the schools closed for the summer holidays last year, and again at Christmas a grant of $15 was allowed for a treat for the children on the Oka Reserve. You should ascertain definitely from the teacher whether she prefers a grant before the school closes for the coming summer holidays or whether she would prefer to receive same next Christmas, as we can only allow this grant for one or other of these occasions. Owing to the many requests received for grants for prizes or treats for the children of the various schools, a considerable sum is expended each year, and we have, therefore, found it necessary to allow the grant once during each year only.

Please consult the teacher in this matter and let us know definitely what she decides.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I am writing to enquire if you would purchase our house for a school house. We have heard you were not going to build a school house in the village because it costs too much. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you offer your house near Oka Village, for school purposes. Some time ago, the Department made arrangements for the erection of a suitable classroom and teacher's residence and I regret that consideration cannot be given to your offer.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Will you please arrange for the purchasing and delivery at Oka of the desks required for the new Oka Day School now under construction, and which I expect will be ready for occupation around the middle of September.

I may say that the desks used at the old school are mostly in poor condition. The best of these desks will be taken and used at the country school where they are in need of a few desks to replace ones that are completely beyond further use.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

The school house is nearing completion. In all probability two or three days work will complete it and will be ready for occupancy.

In view of this I would make requisition for a National Flag which should remain the property of the school. Without it in my opinion the school would be inadequately equipped.

If I understand correctly the objective of our work in Oka, as it should be in all other Indian Reserves is to develop new Canadians and the National Flag will be a big factor in the development and fostering of a National Spirit.

It will be seen how vital and important the flag will be in the life of the growing generation of Indians. It will occupy a place all its own and I can see nothing else to substitute it.

I do hope that the importance of this feature of our work will not be overlooked.

With this must go the erection of a flag staff and so far I have seen no indications of one to be erected.

The staff of workers are still on the ground and with little or no trouble these men could put it up.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Helen Earl.

Dear Sir:

In looking over the New School building I discovered that we would not be properly equipped without well selected pictures or paintings from recognized artists.

It must not be forgotten that we are dealing with children who are mostly in the formative age. It is universally recognized principle that children of this age learn mostly through sight and I feel that provision should be made to meet this requirement.

Cher Monsieur:

que les plans et devis de toute installation électrique
dans un édifice public, classification qui comprend les

des Examinateurs Électriques, ce qui comporte l'honorable

Veuillez donc voir à ce que les plans
de cette installation nous soient envoyés aussitôt
que possible, en même temps que ceux de l'école des
Indiens, à Oka, car cette loi s'applique aussi dans
le cas des écoles.

Vous remerciant à l'avance de la bonne
attention que vous voudrez bien porter à cette affaire,
je serais,

Votre dévoué,

Dear Sir:

I notice that Arbor Day falls on the 7th instant. I have been planning to observe it as in other years but having moved into our new school and location the celebration would demand many new ideas and schemes.

In the first place the grounds should be levelled, which requires a lot of planning and work but the scheme in my opinion is well worth the work. In the second place the trees should be planted along the street and a few trees facing the Teacher's Residence, already I have some flowering shrubs planted.

How much would the Department allow towards carrying out this scheme?

A team of horses would be absolutely necessary and I am interesting the male population to give their labour free. It would require several ladies also to help me prepare meals for these men who volunteer their services.

It will be seen that the expenses which will be incurred are for a team of horses and meals for the men.

The Department will notice that in celebrating the Arbor Day we are departing somewhat from our custom viz: having an objective.

I may say I have postponed celebrating Arbor Day to the 14th instant to allow time for a reply from the Department.

I am sending one copy of this letter to the Agent.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Helen Earl.

Oka, August 27, 1934.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant in connection with Voucher No. 954, for $40.00, in favour of Aqueduc Municipal d'Oka, covering the cost of the water service for the Oka Village Indian Day School from May 1st, 1934 to May 1st, 1935.

You asked me some informations relative to the increase of the cost of the water service pointing out that the Department had only been paying from $6.00 to $7.00 for the same service in the past years.

In reply I beg to inform you that since the foundation of this Village and until May last, the water had been supplied by the Séminaire of St-Sulpice, who were the owner of the aqueduct. Last year, however, as the water service was insufficient for the needs of this locality, the aqueduct was bought by the Municipal Council from the Séminaire, and the whole system had to be built entirely anew, which necessitated an expense of over $45,000. Owing to the considerable expenses encountered in the acquisition and the building up of a new system for the water the Council had to set up a new scale of rates for all the customers.

The commercial and public buildings were charged $40.00 a year for the service of water and the private houses are being charged three times the price they were paying to the Séminaire when on the old system.

However I beg to say that this considerable raise in the cost of water could not be avoided as it was automatically transferred from the Séminaire to the Aqueduc Municipal when the latter took possession of the water service on an order from the Public Utility Commission of the Province of Quebec.

Your obedient servant

It is very urgent to replace those logs in a couple days by the fact that the floor is almost sunk down in the class and they can hardly pass on, and if we do not repair soon they will be obliged to make a new floor later.

Please answer me soon if you authorized me to make that floor repair because it is very dangerous for the children to walk on such a floor.

Probably that you will find that I ask much and often for clothing and material for houses. The Indians are all asking for clothing and material. In that case I will like if the Inspector Mr. McCooking can pass on the Reserve soon, by the fact I am a new agent I do not like to make too many recommendations, and I think it will be better if it is possible for Mr. McCooking to come for both satisfaction.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Dear Sir,

I would ask you to arrange with Mr. Cree to do this work during the Christmas Holidays.

33¢ par mois, pour 2 mois = $0.66
Les premiers 60 kwh, par mois, pour 2 mois: 120 kwh = $0.16

= $4.22

Bien à vous,

Ottawa, July 7, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that you may arrange to have the exterior of the Oka Village Indian Day School building painted. The cost, including material and labour, should not exceed, approximately, the sum of $75.00. You should utilize Indian labour in carrying out the work. I understand Mr. Orr, Architect, of this Department, who recently visited Oka, discussed this matter with you and informed you of the amount of painting that should be performed. Please arrange for the purchase of the paint, from a firm on the approved list, and see that Indians who are competent to do the work are employed.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the paint and other materials used, and also keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, of the labour. These time sheets should show the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid.

I would request that you arrange to have this painting completed during the present summer holidays.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Oka July 15th, 1936

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th, instant in connection with the painting of the Oka Indian Village Day School.

In reply I beg to tell you that I put three men at work Monday morning at the cost of 0.20 per hour, and I bought the paint at the Chene's Store at Oka, paint is $3.85 per gallon, and I must tell you that the amount authorize is not enough to paint that school and there is a little shed near the school that I will like to paint too, and there is few things that I will oblige to repair like the gallery and the inside doors, etc., and with the amount of $75.00 I can not make all those things, and with that said amount I will not get enough to paint the roof of the school, I will like if the Dept. can vote me another amount like $40.00 more to do that work.

Memorandum:

Mr. Christianson
Mr. Phelan

Re Oke Village School

Upon my visit to Oke, Quebec, on the 1st instant, I made a special visit to the above school, and beg to report as follows:

Floor: Beams supporting floor appear to have rotted, although this is rather a new building. Insufficient ventilation has certainly caused timber to spoil. There is no cellar, foundations are of concrete, with very small openings to ventilate. To put the floor in safe condition for the next school year would necessitate the expenditure of about $200.00. The Agent had some supports set under the floor for the time being.

Classroom: Desks should be set on runners to keep them in line; this is not an expensive thing to do. 24 desks have not seen any varnish for a long time and should receive a coat or two to preserve them.

An extra blackboard 10 or 12 feet long is also needed.

The children should be supplied with individual drinking cups. Three dozen enamel cups should be supplied.

The stove in use is obsolete and should be replaced at once; I consider it is a fire menace. It is too bad to keep taking a chance with this one; it would be cheaper to purchase a coal stove than to build a new school. This matter requires immediate attention.

Residence: The walls of one room, 10' x 12' approximately, in the residence, are in great need of varnish, as well as the stairs which were previously painted white. The teacher, Mr. Morley Oke, has offered to put on varnish and paint if it is supplied to him. May I recommend the purchase of one gallon of varnish and three pints of white paint, to cover desks, walls and stairs.

Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.

MINISTÈRE DE LA SANTÉ

May 12th, 1939.

Mr. François Harbour,
Federal Agent for the
Oka Indian Reserve,
OKA.

Dear Sir:

I am reporting on unsanitary conditions existing in both Country and Village Indian Schools. In the Country School, the outside privies are repulsing and the adjoining lot is used as a dumping ground. In the village, the privies outside are also in a very bad condition. I cannot see the reason why these children are not given modern facilities by adopting for these schools inside chemical toilets. And surely cleanliness should be strictly in force in these establishments.

The Law and our Provincial Rules demand that no child should be admitted in school if not vaccinated against smallpox. Out of 66 pupils only one is vaccinated. It is my duty to ask you to see that vaccination will be made in a very near future. I will make a control visit in eight days, after which the person in charge of the schools shall refuse to admit any child not vaccinated.

Very truly yours,

P.S. A copy of this letter is sent to Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare and Training, Ottawa.

(Sgd.) Dr. Jean L. Faille, D.P.H.
Ottawa,
May 15, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department is just in receipt of a copy of a letter dated the 13th instant from Dr. Jean Louis Faillle, D.M.R. The first paragraph of this letter reads as follows:

"I am reporting on unsanitary conditions existing in both Country and Village Indian Schools. In the Country School, the outside privies are repulsing and the adjoining lot is used as a dumping ground. In the village, the privies outside are also in a very bad condition. I cannot see the reason why these children are not given modern facilities by adopting for these schools inside chemical toilets. And surely cleanliness should be strictly in force in these establishments."

Please make immediate arrangements for cleaning the toilets at both the Oka Village and Oka Country schools.

It is difficult to understand why you have permitted conditions to become such that Dr. Faillle finds it necessary to make the report shown above, especially in view of the very large number who are on relief in the Oka Agency. There is no reason why work of the nature required should not be done by those on relief.

The Department will expect to hear from you within a week that the conditions about which Dr. Faillle complains have been fully rectified.

Yours truly,

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, Que.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Director

Report of Inspection of the Oka Caughnawaga and St. Regis Reserves.

OKA RESERVE

The school in the village was visited. The school teacher reported that many of the children were away with colds, and that the school was very cold. As a result, attendance had been very poor. Apparently, the floor in the school needs repairing. The sills have rotted away and the floors have sunk, leaving cracks through which cold air blows, and it makes it impossible to keep the building warm with a stove, unless some repair work is done. Cod liver oil is being sent to the school.

The other school was not visited as the roads were impassible.

Dear Sir:

With reference to requisition dated the 16th instant you may purchase for use at the Oka Village Day School the following articles:

You may also purchase a pair of hinges and make the necessary repairs to the two doors which do not close properly.

Dear Sir;-

I wish to refer to your letters dated October 17th and 22nd dealing with repairs needed at the above School and in this connection to advise that at my last visit at Oka I made a throughout inspection of the building.

May I say that since the visit of Mr. Doucet other joists gave away with the result that not only the floor of the girl's and boy's entrance are sagging badly but also the floor of the class and that of the teacher's quarters.

The side beams supporting the joists are all rotten, the main beam is broken in the middle and the rought floor has rotted. The joists are almost all rotten and the only support to the building are the posts which have been put from time to time to support the floors. The only thing left is the hard wood floor and it is feared for the safety of the pupils as the floor might give way at any time.

In view of the condition of this building I would strongly suggest that an official of the Branch be sent to Oka in order to make the necessary suggestions.

It is believed that the repairs needed will cost a few hundreds of dollars.

Yours very truly

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt., of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Your telegram dated the 17th instant, and reading as follows, has been received:

"Employ Mr. Boileau carpenter Oka make necessary repairs Oka Country School Department will depend on teacher and yourself to keep cost as low as possible"

In connection with this matter I may say that Mr. Boileau was interviewed this morning while I was at Oka and we visited the School together—incidentally your telegram was referring to the Country School but it is doubtless an error as previous correspondence was about the Village School. Due to the extent of the repairs to be made and to the fact that the School will have to be closed it is suggested that more than one carpenter be employed. Mr. Boileau states that it is not possible for a man to work alone on this repair job and it is suggested that one or two other carpenters be employed.

As this work will be made by the day I would appreciate being advised where the necessary materials such as lumber, nails, tar paper etc., will be purchased. Also to be given the name or names of other men who should be employed and also let me know if the Department will attend to all repairs mentioned in the estimates remitted to Mr. Phelan at his last visit here.

Mr. Boileau informs me that his price per hour is of $0.81 which he says is the regular price paid in the region and also on Defence projects.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supp., of Welfare and Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
I was also informed by the teacher that every winter the school and the residence are without water. This is stated to be due to the fact that the pipe connecting the building with the main pipe in the street is only 3½ feet underground instead of being 5 feet.

Kindly send me your instructions at your earliest convenience. If deemed necessary or advisable the visit of Mr. Thibeault, Inspector, would be appreciated in order to complete arrangements for the above.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Three weeks ago tomorrow Mr. Brisebois showed me your wire to go ahead with repairs on our school building. I was to supervise with him to keep, as your message said, "the costs low." Repairs started last Saturday week, November 29th, 1941.

Tile pipe has been laid and cemented. The cement job was done after my insisting the sand would block the whole system if the joints were not covered over. I did, however, suggest iron pipes, with couplings, but the contractor said it was more expensive and he could not lose money. It is a nice chap.

The 30 ft. of tile pipe laid was just down from 6' to 1 below the surface. As the length of pipes was still uncovered I suggested that Mr. Brisebois in question...
was in town they should leave the lower end (of a shallow depression) uncovered till he had inspected it. In my humble judgment backed up by others whom I sought information on such matters (I forget who) was only courting disaster; that since the great foes 3' into the ground such pipes ought to go down 4' anyway.

Furthermore, I added, during the observance of Arbor Day in our schools throughout the Dominion a piece of wood very likely accomplish what the frost in your judgment apparently would not do. For good measure, in my admittedly poor French, I said to the workmen: The next farmer here may be a married man and want every foot of soil to cultivate for vegetables to raise his family. He brings in now a horse plow. What is the answer now but possibly splintered pipes because such a plow will likely go down more than a foot?

The pipes were covered up before Mr. Breton's had arrived. He assured me, on my word, that there...
necessary precautions, that the work was guaranteed, so if it did not work right they would have to do the job right later on. But now is the time I told him.

Perhaps Mr. Brisbois has already told you of my repeated efforts to have the water pipe put down deeper. It freezes every year because it is only down 3 ft. The Contractor's argument was that the fact the knacker could thaw out the pipe showed that the pipe under the street, or rather the pipe from the street was not frozen. I rejoined, it would have frozen but the knacker had for bury at the other end and did not give it a chance to freeze up the entire length. He had no reply to that.

May I again repeat what Mr. Brisbois knows that in case of freezing up not only is the sewage system useless but at once a fire hazard is created. And that place would go up in smoke in a few minutes. It were criminal negligence to let this go and I know you will see it as I do.
For Morrison, the water pipe from the street should go down 5' anyway and should be fitted in a saw duct from the ground to the floor of the house. I would like your authorization regarding this when the present work contract is finished. I would suggest that the Indians should be given this work, as is the paint work on the school, which the present workers have discussed with Mr. Brossard for next spring.

I hope I may be permitted to add one thing more regarding our fuel needs. Every wood shed in the Village Pass seems pretty well stocked up for the winter. Why has ours been kept so low in wood? The janitor asks for dry wood (6-12). Two weeks ago there was no heating for the morning. I gave my own personal cheque for a cord of dry wood ($2.50). That is not food enough. In my kitchen I have a 20-year-old brick-lined Quebec heater that simply will not warm a pot of tea unless filled up with combustibles, and is patched up like a boiler with adhesive tape. This is another pipe hazard because of a crack in it.
I am glad to feel you are cooperating with us here. Mr. Brisebois and I get along fine. He has delegated to me his authority in the repairs when he is not here. I appreciated very much your confidence in me too to do some supervision and we hope for future built-in closets and a shower for our pupils.

School is closed for 2 weeks until the repairs have been effected. Meanwhile some of the older girls are learning how to make Xmas decorations from an old Indian woman and the prospects for their sale in Montreal are pretty well assured by some friends of ours in Westmount. The proceeds are to go to the school or to meet some local needs.

Again thanking you for all that you are doing for the Oka Village School.

Respectfully Yours,

George Wilkinson

* We had baskets for basketball plus a water tap in school. Mr. Brisebois is sympathetic to this. Also, at noon a wash basin and bath (as well as the toilet) in the teachers' room.

† We gathered some hundreds of pine cones, with Mr. Brisebois' permission, a month ago, and are now very useful in our work.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant enclosing a communication sent to Ottawa by Mr. Wilkinson, teacher, in which he complained against the work being presently done at the School where he is teaching.

You will note that the Contractor had submitted an estimate of eight different items for a total of $788.00. The work has been done satisfactorily and is now terminated with the exception of a bath and water basin in the teacher's residence also a water tap and basin in the classroom which are now being installed.

Relative to the complaint about the tile pipe laid from the cesspool to the back of the school yard I may say that the teacher had insisted with the contractor that iron pipe be used instead of tile. As you know tile is always used for such purpose and the price of this work was based on tile not on iron pipe. As to its depth into the ground its runs from three feet to one and one half foot. It was not possible to put it deeper owing to the ground level of the yard and also of the surrounding properties. The contractor assures that this work is fully guaranteed and that if this cesspool does not function well it will be made anew free of charge to the Department.

As to the possibility of a teacher planting vegetables at the School, it is not to my knowledge that schoolyards are used as such, but as playgrounds.

Mr. Wilkinson apparently caused trouble to the contractor in asking him to do additional work than that contracted for. For instance he wanted the pipe (water) from the main pipe in the street,

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt., of Welfare and Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
to the building to be lowered from its present depth, which he claims is three and one half feet, to five feet. The distance from the main pipe to the school is of about 60 feet and this work was not contracted for. He also wanted the bath and wash basin as well as the water in the class room installed immediately, that is before it was authorized.

The contractor had been informed not to incur any additional expenses nor do other work in addition to his contract before getting the proper authorization.

As to showers for the pupils I may say that this might be quite well in a residential school for the teacher should realize that his is a day school and that mostly all his suggestions have been approved he ought to be satisfied. The present outside toilets have completely been repaired and are in good condition. At all events due to the present conditions this cannot be recommended.

May I say that the recent attitude of the teacher is not well understood. He left Oka on Saturday last, and left no key for the contractor and apparently none, or gave orders, to the janitor not to give the key to anyone with the result that the work could not be terminated on Saturday as the men could not get into the building. On my trip to Oka on Monday, last, the 15th, I called for the key and the janitor stated not to have any, that the teacher had left with same and was still away.

I had to use one of my keys to gain entrance to the building and gave instructions for the work to be proceeded with. It is not well understood why the teacher went away and took such an attitude. The water might have frozen thus causing damages and at the same time it delayed the completion of the work for two days. When I left Oka on Tuesday evening the teacher had not yet returned.

Mr. Wilkinson's letter is herewith enclosed.

Yours very truly

Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Two am today I wired you as follows:

"Regret inform you suspended Oka School repairs December 13 most serious reasons. Contractor with assistant trucked away Dec. 6, without permission, hard wood flooring in excellent condition. December 11 gave contractor strict orders to bring back wood taken away and take nothing in future. Same occasion, Dec. 11, I revealed to him work in cellar unsatisfactory because four rotten beams left in place thus proving sooner or later detrimental to stability of building. December 12 both individuals repeated same kind offence."
even unlocking our wood shed for little
remainder from repair job. Agent Brisbois
had promised us the wood from repairs.
Community watching developments. Letter
follows. Suggest Federal Police and Engineer
look over ground. (Sgd.) George Williamson.

At 3 p.m. today I wired you again
as follows:

The Oka School repairs message
number two. Immediate recovery wood from
Contractor etc. absolutely essential name law
and order as well as Manual Training needs
fuel requirements as per Agent Brisbois
promise re wood. Moreover, chronic wood
shortages constitute threat this little school,
menace teacher pupils health, imperil good
relations between sufferers and responsible
parties, besides inviting public enquiry
to throw spotlight on nigger in wood-
pile. Collecting clothing Montreal for pupils
sold $20 worth. Times demand. Seeking
develop this initiative in spirit your policy.
(Sgd.) George Williamson.
Now to elaborate a little on the situation created by this event.

The Town is asking what shall be done to these men (the Contractor is the Policeman!)?

Indians go to jail for theft, why not these Irishmen?

The Indians suffered all manner of persecution last century. They ask, is our school likewise to suffer in 1941?

Personally I think an attempt might be made by certain elements here to create an "incident." I tell you and all who handling our affairs that if the necessary precautions are not taken, I will have no atom unturned to bring to justice the nigger in the woodpile, long in hiding. Only a firm hand can meet successfully this situation which at present is a white blacksmith, on Saturday playing the role of Justice, now turned Government Contractor.

As an individual he is not a bad egg and is easily frightened, as I did when I talked to him in my kitchen last Thursday about his rotten work and theft. I had
gone on all fours the night before to inspect their work in the cellar. At first he had the nerve to contradict but when I mentioned two 3 beam from the hatch another from the wall to the mid-section of the building he gave up the ghost, and promised to do it for nothing extra. They were then laying the top flooring of hard wood.

I persisted with him: "Why are you not using the hard wood you men took up instead? All new hard wood?" He was "pleased" he said. I denied it. "There was a great deal that could have been used," I added.

"Where is this hard wood gone? Have you taken it?" "Yes," he admitted. "And you men the other?" "Yes." Mr. Brink's promised me that wood to have it sawn up....

He offered several "alibis" at this time: The wood taken was his "pride;" that it was "out in the rain;" that the "boys would have taken it;" and when I replied to all this nonsense and ordered him
to return it at once saying that if he dared to steal wood from his own Catholic school he would soon have to bring it back he replied he would put it up for "public auction." "Who owns this wood, you or the school?" no reply.

Later on he had the nerve to threaten me with being discharged "if I believe all the Indians said." I am not anti-Catholic, mark you; but I know my rights and will stand up for them against any or all. That's that.

When I cautioned him in my miserable French, his assistant boss to take nothing more he mumbled in French and turned away showing his deep resentment at being caught red-handed. That was on a Thursday, Dec. 11th.

I instructed him our janitor to pick up all the old wood lying about the yard as our new wood was about out, and put it in the woodshed. The following day, Friday, Dec. 12th, on my return from the pines where some half-dozen young Indians were learning the
art & wreath-making from an old Indian woman, our schoolmaster informed me that during my absence the contractor's assistant had taken away all the new wood (hardwood etc.) left over from the job and even unlocked our wood shed and stolen what he had piled there the day before. I had given him orders to stop anybody from away with any new wood. He confirmed he could not "trust himself" to go out and complete the job. He is an Iroquois, a returned man. I need add nothing more as to what might have happened.

I thereupon ordered the doors to be kept locked; to inform them if they came back next day, Saturday, Dec. 13, I had gone out of town and was waiting for instructions from Ottawa before permitting them to continue with the job.

You will also recall, sir, that these men did not obey instructions from me not to cover up those sewage pipes until Mr. Brinbois could see them. The trouble is
They think they can get away with it.

I may make a suggestion:

A letter from you to the contractor pointing out our disappointment at not getting what Brisbois had promised. That opening up our shed, taking out our wood puts him under Criminal law (as a lawyer told me yesterday), and that the Dept., even if it permits him finishing the job, has it in its power to deduct for the value of the hard wood at least, which could have been used again; and that he is not sheltering from the tax collector but the public treasury and is guilty of contempt of law (since I represented the Ottawa York.) would undoubtedly have a salutary effect. Also, to see this man or men, bringing some of the stuff back would also have a most salutary effect on the nerves & the Community.

Oh H.C. in P. official for a good sound talking to would have an lasting beneficial effects on him and his kind about here.

He is a weakling. Make the most of it.
Gaughnawaga, Que.,
January 6, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo enclosing a communication from Mr. Wilkinson, teacher at the Oka Village School which contained serious accusations and complaints against the contractor doing the work at the above School.

In reply I wish to inform you that after having investigated it has been found that the statements made by the teacher were erroneous. The contract was conducted according to the price submitted and not one iota was neglected, on the contrary the contractor made several other minor repairs in order to please the teacher, without any charge.

Mr. Wilkinson was interviewed and could not substantiate any of his statements but merely stated that he wrote you because he was only going to the Reserve once a week and stated that his letters only contained informations which he thought in order (he did not know that his letters had been forwarded back to me). He also stated to be quite pleased with the improvements authorized and the work done.

The teacher was apparently under the influence of the janitor of that School, Adam Montour, who used to be a recognised drunkard and had once been arrested by the contractor, who is also the Village Constable. The letter is herewith returned.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th of January last, returning the accounts for the installation of a bathroom in the residence of the teacher at the Ola Village School in which you request explanation regarding the labor charged.

In reply I wish to let you know that after having interviewed the contractor I was informed that this bathroom which was installed on the second story of the residence required more work than an ordinary job. It is stated that mostly all the water pipes in the cellar had to be replaced owing to the fact that it was badly rusted and that if this had not been done early trouble would have been encountered as the pipes were leaking at several places, which accounted for the fact that the water was freezing every winter for the past few years. The work in the cellar, it was stated, was difficult as it is very low.

The bathroom was installed in a closet adjoining the teacher's room upstairs. There was no window in it and one had to be opened as well as a ventilator and a new floor made. The electricity also had to be installed and a linoleum put on the floor.

All the above was supplied by the contractor who charged it in labor instead of having separate accounts sent. The accounts also cover the water tap in the class room.

Yours very truly,

R. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt., of Welfare and Education,

July 25, 1944.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the report from Doctor Leonard Milot regarding the Oka Schools. As you know, we have already authorized the painting of the Oka Country School. If you consider it necessary to paint the interior of the Oka Village School, you should let me have an estimate of the cost.

It is not our intention to install, at the present time, the type of toilets recommended by the Medical Officer. However, you should make certain that the toilets at present in use are clean and kept in that condition throughout the academic year.

If it is possible to change the seating arrangement in the school in order to have the light from the left side, you should do so.

If any repairs are required to the walls at the schools the Department approves your arranging for the necessary work.

R.A. Hoey,

I wish to transmit you herewith voucher no. 353, in the amount of $86.40 for labour in the painting of the classroom of the Oka Village School.

On receipt of your letter of the 25th of July last, estimates were asked for the cost of the above work. Two estimates were received from Painting Contractors; one was for $200.00 the other for $163.40. This was thought too high and the prices declined.

In the middle of August, Mr. Paul Jacobs offered to take this job by the hour and to do it for approximately $86.00, material excluded. This price was accepted and the work completed for the beginning of September or in time for the opening of the School.

Three coats of paint were put on, one coat of flat and two coats of gloss paint. The ceiling was painted white and the walls in a light green color. The floor was also washed, cleaned and oiled.

The above work was necessary as the classroom was too dark. It is finished with B.C. Fir and the walls and ceiling had not been touched since the school was built. The windows are on the north side and there is never any sun in that class. The bright colors applied have brightened the building considerably.

(Fr. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Caughnawaga, Que.
September 28, 1945.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re:- Votes Nos. 76691 & 76693

You will note that $350.00 has been stated in the estimates 1946-47 towards the painting of the Oka Village School.

Your records will show the last time this School was painted.

At present this building is badly in need of paint and it is believed that three coats of paint will be needed to make a fair job.

Please give this item your consideration.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 3, 1945.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you state you are including an item of $350.00 in the estimates for 1946-47 for the painting of the Oka Village School. Your recommendation in this regard will receive every possible consideration when the estimates are being prepared.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 2nd instant in which, among other matters discussed, you state that the Estimates for 1946-47 for the Oka Agency have not been received at the Branch.

In this connection I may say that these have been sent together with those of Caughnawaga. The estimates for both Reserves were mailed in the same envelope together with letters of comments also concerning the painting of the Schools for Oka and Caughnawaga. A reply relative to the painting of the Oka Village School has already been received signed by Mr. Phelan-file 20-2-5 dated October 3rd, 1945, in which my communication of the 28th ultimo, sent with the estimates, is quoted.

If the estimates for Oka have not been received or mislead please advise me when a copy of same will be forwarded you. In that event kindly send me the necessary forms.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re:- Oka Indian Village School.

I wish to bring to your attention the matter of the water supply at the above School.

The pipe connecting the Municipal main in the street, from the School building, is only located at a depth of three feet in the ground. Every year this system freezes which causes considerable inconvenience to the teachers who have to get their water supply from neighbors for their own use and that of the pupils.

May I suggest that the pipe in question be lowered to a depth of 5½ or 6 feet and covered with boards in order to remedy to the situation.

At my last visit at Oka, Mr. Henri Carriere, Plumber, submitted a price for the whole work. Said price to be between $50.00 and $60.00 at the most. This would comprise the digging, connecting of pipe and also its change of location in the cellar as it runs too near the foundation.

I would recommend that this work be undertaken at present before the frost sets in.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to bring to your attention the bad condition of the Oka Indian Village School as far as the paint is concerned.

The exterior of that School has not been painted for over 12 years and at the present time there is practically no paint left. What remains of the paint should all be scraped off and three coats of paint required in order to make a fair job.

This school which is located in the center of the Village was built about 20 years ago and I am informed was only painted once since its construction.

Will you kindly let me know if the Branch would approve of its painting after tenders for the job have been asked.

May I point out that the exterior has never been decorated since the school was built and is also in urgent need of paint.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Referring to your letter of the 7th of July, last, in which you authorized the painting of the Oka Indian Village School, I wish to inform that the outside painting of that School has been terminated. A first class job was made by the two Indian painters. Photos of this School will be sent you in the near future.

In connection with the above work I have to advise that twelve gallons of paint have been left over, and in this regard I would suggest that this be exchanged with the merchant who supplied same for interior paint and that the painting of the four rooms and the toilet room of the residence be undertaken.

The interior is of B.C. Fir finish and has never been varnished nor painted since the construction of the School, about twenty-two years ago. It is very dark and almost impossible to keep clean. Electricity has to be used all day except for two or three hours of the day.

The painters are estimating that the twelve gallons of paint would be sufficient for the three coats of paint required on the walls and ceiling of this residence. The cost for the labour for the three coats to be of $200.00.

In addition the boys and the girls entrance to the School which are of 15 x 12, B.C. Fir finish, could be undertaken at a price of $40.00 for two coats. Four gallons of paint would be required. These entrances are 12 feet high.
As you are aware the classroom of this School, which was also of B.C. Fir finish, was painted a few years ago and is actually in fair condition.

If authorization for the painting of the residence and that of the entrances is given, we will have a building in first class condition and we will be a few years without having to spend any money on its upkeep.

I would kindly ask you to take the foregoing into consideration as it is considered to be necessary improvements.

(Prs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
September 7, 1943.

You may also purchase four gallons of paint that is required. It is noted that you have twelve gallons of paint on hand. You may exchange this for interior paint.

When painting the exterior of the Oka Indian Village School, in the course of last summer, the bell of that school which had not been used for several years, was taken down and stored in the shed on the school property.

This bell would be available for transfer. It is in first class condition. Its weight being over 250 pounds.

Please advise if it would be of use elsewhere.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
November 17, 1948.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.,

We have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to the bell that is not required at the Oka Village School.

At the present time, we are not aware of any other school where such a heavy bell is required. If there is any possibility of selling it you might let us know for what amount it could be sold and also the name and address of the person to whom the sale could be made. We will then be in a position to submit the matter to the Salvage Office for approval before completing the actual sale.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Nous avons eu une vie accidentellement le 26 juillet 1887, et nous avons pu faire l'école des Indiens pendant trois ans, maintenant je vais aller demeurer sur les lieux de la rivière Kitchena où j'ai quelques garçons qui sont encore à l'école sous le bon soin de la mère d'une famille de pontage au fort, dont 5 filles et six garçons vivent là, nous donnant en détail afin que vous jugiez si je suis une femme utile à mon pays et à notre Souverain, le Royaume de la France.

Le dernier, Honorable Monsieur,

Sir,

I sent to Mr. Marcotte, Indian Agent, the quarterly school report for the last quarter of the school year for the school on the Pointe Bleue Reserve. I have given in my resignation as teacher. It has been accepted and a young woman has been appointed in my place.

I conducted the school for ten years assisted by my daughter. I have always done my best and I have never received any reproach from the Department.

As there is no well on the school-house grounds, I was obliged to pay from two to three dollars a year for the supply of water for the school. The school was always swept by my assistant, and I had it washed several times at my own expense. Therefore, Sir, in consideration of my ten years' service I shall be very much obliged to you if you will give me one quarter's salary as a benefit.

Pointe Bleue, Aug. 23, 1904.

Sir,

I learnt a few days ago that Miss Marie Eliz. Girard, who replaced Mrs. O.P. Dufresne as teacher at the Pointe Bleue school and who promised me to retake her class in Sept., was married during the holidays and that consequently she will not teach school any more. When she left on July 1, last, her returns were not complete, so that before asking for her salary I had to demand that they be completed.

I have now in my hands four applications from teachers for the next school year; one from Mrs. (Widow) Roy, of Peribonka, another from her daughter, Angelina Roy; another from Miss Laetitia Gagnon, of Roberval, and lastly a fourth from Mrs. Joseph Cleary, of the Pointe Bleue reserve. Of the four applicants only two have diplomas, Mrs. Roy and Mrs. Joseph Cleary. Mrs. Roy is certainly an experienced teacher. Her intention, if she should get the school, would be to live in it with one of her daughters; to which I believe I ought to object for the following reasons: the school-house is too small to accommodate two persons, and then I believe that that would necessitate extra cost in heating, without taking into account the constant danger of fire. On the other hand Mrs. Joseph Cleary by her marriage became a member of the band. She resides very near the
school-house. She holds a diploma and she has already taught school several years among white people. She would undertake to light the fire in the school-house half an hour before school opens and not to leave the building until the fire would be quite out. Under the circumstances I should recommend her appointment in preference to the other. I have written on this subject to the school inspector for the county, and I believe that he will have no objection to her appointment. I believe, also, that it would be difficult, without displeasing almost the whole band, to set aside one of themselves, as capable as any person in the matter of teaching. Mrs. Roy would like very much to obtain the school, but under the circumstances, as there is an application from a qualified Indian woman, I believe it my duty to recommend the latter, and I hope to receive, shortly, authority to engage Mr. Joseph Cleary.

I have, etc.,

Alphonse Marcoux,

Sir,

With reference to complaints of Mrs. Joseph Cleary (The Less) contained on file number 152684-1 I beg to say that for the following reasons they appear to be well grounded. The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mrs. Cleary, teacher of the Pointe Bleue Indian school writes the Department stating that she has been informed by several persons that Mr. Tessier had told them that he is going to have her dismissed. Mr. Tessier evidently bears a spite against Mrs. Cleary on account of the investigation lately held by Mr. Inspector Macrae into his dealings with her. The poor woman seems to be much exercised over the report and is anxious to retain her position, as she has been left a widow with a family to support.

I think the Department would be quite justified in easing her mind by telling her that it has no desire to dispense with her services at present. My reason for making this recommendation is based on Mr. Inspector Savard's report on this school, of January 9, last, from which I make the following quotations:

"This school, for the second year under the charge of Mrs. Cleary, nee Felixine Riversin, has made astonishing progress since my last visit; for many years discipline had never been so well maintained; the pupils continue to like their teacher, and out of 50 pupils 33 attend regularly."

"Mrs. Cleary gives a good careful education: I hope she may continue for several years as teacher of this school, which renders such great service to these poor Indians; besides, the present teacher has this year obtained the most satisfactory results, and the Govt. can never, I believe, entrust this school to a teacher more devoted, who has the esteem not only of the children but of the parents as well."

Sir,

As you must have learned through the Agent, I gave up teaching the Indians at Pointe Bleue on Oct. 7 last, for the sole reason that I married a man belonging to the white race; consequently I was not able to continue my class and finish my year, which was very hard upon me, for I should have liked very much to continue in your service. I shall be very grateful to you, Mr. Secretary, if I may be paid my salary for the month of Oct. and also for the forty cords of wood that my deceased husband, the late Joseph Cleary, supplied to the Agent. In the month of Jan. last, on the occasion of the visit of Mr. Macrae, I was given good hope: Mr. Macrae promised me that he would send me this money as soon as possible through the Agent and I have not learned anything since. Do not be astonished if I claim it for the first time, for I am absolutely in need of it: my late husband left me four children with nothing, and you will understand these little orphans are in need of this money to provide for their wants. All the same, I know that it is not your fault that my husband was deceived by your Agent, Mr. Tessier, for you did not give any order to cut this wood; but I ask you, Mr. Secretary, in whom ought the poor Indians to confide if not the Agent whom you have commissioned to administer to them. If the Agent selected by you is not a man to be trusted, is that the fault of the poor Indians? I think not. So, if you please, pay me this money, and I shall be very thankful to you.

Felexine Riverin

Sir,

I have to direct your attention to official letter of the 10th April in which you were informed that your son-in-law, Mr. Tessier, acting on your behalf, took advantage of his position in 1904 to give the school teacher, Mrs. Cleary, to understand that her salary was $250.00 a year, (not $300.00, the amount which the Department had agreed to pay) and that her engagement as teacher was dependent upon her husband, the late Mr. Cleary, furnishing Mr. Tessier with 40 cords of wood, at $1.25 per cord. It appears that 33 cords of wood were supplied under this arrangement, and value in driving Mr. Tessier, his wife and family was rendered up to the amount of $41.25.

As pointed out to you in the letter above quoted Mr. Tessier admitted to the Inspector Macrae the truth of the facts as set forth in the claim which has been made by Mrs. Cleary, now Mrs. Géminas Tremblay.

Owing to your position as Indian Agent the Department holds you responsible in this matter. I have therefore to request that you will be good enough to at once forward to the Department the sum of $50.00 in settlement of this claim. Report for Mr. Pedley:

Pointe Bleue and day schools -

There are 54 habitations on this reserve, at least three-fourths of which belong to Indians, who, as Father Lemoine says, are absent for 10 months in the year. The families with school children that are fairly regular residents on the reserve number ten or twelve and are those known as "the halfbreeds".

These are all sufficiently served by the existing school, which they are and have been attending. The distance travelled to reach it is no hardship for the twelve children for whom another school is asked reside at distances ranging from about three-quarters of a mile to two miles from the existing one and the road is a good one, well travelled.

Were a school established at the N. E. corner of the reserve to serve the few children there, who are within the distance stated from the present school, and who have already much better facilities than many children in our back settlements, the only way to keep up an attendance that would justify its maintenance would be to permit the attendance of the children of French settlers along the St. Prime road. These could be got in considerable numbers within a distance of three-fourths to two miles from the N. E. corner and for them a school there would prove to be a great convenience.

No qualified teacher could be got, of course, for any such sum as the Reverend Father indicates.

As to educating the children of resident Indians, therefore, I am of the opinion that the pre-
present school furnishes means enough.

As to educating those of the non-resident or hunting Indians, who only come in to the reserve for six weeks or two months annually, I am of opinion that to attempt to do so would be useless unless by means of a boarding school, and, favourable as I am and have always been to the education of Indian children, it seems to me that for some generations hunting and trapping will afford the best means of support to these Indians and that the best training for their children is in those pursuits.

Sir,

Herewith you will find the quarterly report of the teacher of the Pointe Bleue school accompanied by her account. A nun could teach the children many things that a young lay teacher could hardly do, such as sewing, singing, and music. She could even gather together from time to time the young girls of the reserve who no longer go to school, organize with them little dramatic evenings, &c. I consider that from all points of view a nun would assist considerably by her work in raising education in the band. Sir,

In view of the rather considerable increase in the number of children at present attending the Pointe Plouc school, I believe that the engagement of a nun as assistant to the present teacher would be opportune. Indeed a single teacher, in spite of all her good wishes, is not able to teach all the branches of the course that she ought to give to such a large number of children. The average number of pupils attending the school is about 48.

An assistant teacher would be able to take charge of the instruction of the young pupils from six to eight years of age, while the other would undertake the education of the more advanced pupils, and would be able to devote to them a larger part of her time. This certainly would be to the advantage of all the pupils, who, I am sure, would make much greater progress than they are doing at present, owing to their too great number under the control of a single teacher.

Now, before writing this letter, I applied to the Superior of the nuns of Good Counsel, the community to which the present teacher belongs, in order to ascertain what they would charge for the services of such an assistant. She asks the same amount as is received by the present teacher, namely, $300 a year. She certainly would not have asked more than $150 a year if the Oblate Fathers had not intervened and asked her not to ask less than $300, giving as a reason that the Government is rich and has the means to pay good salaries to its teachers. I consider that the
amount that she demands—$300—is really too high. Besides,
this teacher would have much less to do than the principal
she would have much less knowledge to display, because her
work does not call for much brain work to teach the alphabet
and mental arithmetic.

I remarked to the Superior that one could obtain
the services of a young girl with a diploma to act as
assistant teacher for much less than $300. She replied
that she would not consent to a lay woman acting as
assistant to a teacher who is a nun, that that would be
against the rules of her community. She insisted on $300
because the Oblate Fathers of Pointe Bleue told her that
she would get it. For my part, if the Department should
come to the conclusion to engage an assistant teacher,
I believe that a salary of more than $150 ought not to be
offered, as I am persuaded that this remuneration would be
absolutely fair in consideration of the work to be accom-
plished.

On having the services of an assistant teacher,
it would be necessary to divide the school into two sepa-
rate classes, one for the small children under the charge
of the assistant, and the other for the more advanced
pupils under the control of the principal. In order to do
this it would be necessary to make a wooden partition
dividing the school in two. This partition ought to be made
in panels that could be put up and removed at will so that
when entertainments are given by the pupils, or in other
circumstances, the interior of the school could be changed
into a single large hall. After obtaining information on
this subject, I believe that one could have made a movable
partition with panels such as mentioned above for from
$25.00 to $30.00.

In humbly submitting the whole for the consid-
eration of the Department,

I have, so,

A. Temples

Monsieur le Sérénissime,

J'ai l'honneur de vous présenter mon rapport général pour l'année 1912-13.

Il n'y a eu, dans le cours de cette année, aucun événement saillant. Les progrès se continuent. Au point de vue éducatif comme au point de vue agricole, industriel ou commercial, le Lac-St-Jean se développe et se transforme sous la poussée vigoureuse et féconde de ses habitants et... du gouvernement sans doute par les généreux octrois qu'il accorde chaque année.

Dans toutes les municipalités, les salaires ont été augmentés de 15 à 20%. Pour les écoles élémentaires, la moyenne des salaires est de $445.00 contre $128.12 en 1911-12 ; pour les écoles modèles, cette moyenne n'est que de $165.00 contre $162.00 l'année dernière, parce que la plupart de ces écoles sont tenues par des religieuses ou d'anciennes institutrices, qui sont moins attachées à l'argent qu'à leurs chers élèves ; probablement aussi parce que le gouvernement, pour ces écoles, n'a fixé aucun minimum, ce qui aurait dû être fait. Mais je suis heureux de vous dire qu'à l'avenir ces salaires seront portés à deux cents piastres et plus.

J'inscris dans un tableau d'honneur la liste des municipalités qui ont accordé un salaire minimum de $150.00 à leurs institutrices, savoir : Saint-Gédéon, Saint-André, Sainte-Edwidge, Saint-Jérôme, village, Roberval, paroisse, Saint-Prime, Rivière-au-Doré, Sainte-Lucie-d'Albanel, Saint-Edouard-de-Peribonka et la Pointe-de-la-Savanne. Cette liste aurait été beaucoup plus longue si au dernier moment quelques-unes des municipalités les mieux disposées n'avaient pas été obligées d'engager quelques institutrices non-diplômées et sans référence.

Il est regrettable que notre comté soit aussi pauvre en institutrices. Cinquante-huit écoles ont été tenues par des jeunes filles sans diplôme. Quelques-unes de ces personnes ont certes de bonnes dispositions, et celles-là, je les engage à se présenter, mais c'est le petit nombre ; la masse ne donne point satisfaction. En certains cas, il vaudrait autant laisser les écoles fermées.
La solution de ce problème du personnel enseignant est très éloignée, tant que l'enseignement ne sera point devenu une carrière enviee, par conséquent, tant que les salaires n'auront pas atteint au moins le double de ceux d'aujourd'hui. D'autre part, cette augmentation est intimement liée à la compétence des institutrices.

Un beau mouvement cependant qui se manifeste depuis deux ou trois ans, et que je suis heureux de vous signaler, c'est l'établissement de six nouvelles écoles modèles dans les paroisses de Saint-Michel-de-Mississimi, Saint-André, Rivière-au-Doré, Saint-Prime, Saint-Edouard-de-Pérignonka et Sainte-Lucie-d'Albanet, ce qui en porte le nombre à treize.

Ces nouvelles classes, en effet, tout en relevant le niveau de l'instruction, contribueront à nous préparer un plus grand nombre de jeunes filles à l'enseignement. Une maille manquait à la chaîne. Dans un trop grand nombre de paroisses, il y avait un vide, entre la petite école élémentaire et le couvent ou l'école normale, que bien peu songeaient à franchir,—les parents étant ou trop pauvres ou pas assez convaincus des aptitudes de leurs enfants pour entreprendre de plus fortes dépenses.

Il me fait plaisir de constater que ces classes sont bien suivies. Des enfants qui avaient abandonné la petite école pour toujours sont retournés à l'école modèle ; que disje, des institutrices, non diplômées sans doute, sont descendues de la tribune pour aller s'asseoir aux rangs des élèves afin de continuer des études, qu'elles n'auraient jamais reprises sans l'accès facile de ces classes.

Ce cours qui était suivi par 177 élèves en 1916 l'est maintenant par 227, ce nombre ne devra qu'augmenter.

Ainsi donc, ces écoles, tout en répandant une instruction plus solide et plus avancée, permettront au Lac Saint-Jean d'avoir ses institutrices, de compter sur ses propres forces.

Sur les six écoles nouvelles construites en 1912, je n'en ai reçu que deux. Les autres ne sont pas terminées ou devront subir d'importantes améliorations avant de pouvoir l'être.

À l'avenir je vais inviter les municipalités à montrer plus de prudence dans l'octroi des contrats, et à solder moins promptement la note des entrepreneurs.
Aucune école ne devrait être reçue que six mois après la fin des travaux. Une retenue de dix à quinze pour cent devrait être aussi faite pour couvrir les risques des municipalités.

She is an excellent teacher, giving us thorough satisfaction, and she will replace Sister Mary of the Holy Rosary to advantage.

Besides, I thought it well to obtain information in regard to her, and I enclose herewith a letter from Mr. Jolly, school inspector, in respect to her ability as a teacher.

I attach also to this letter, for the information of the Department, reports from Inspector Jolly to the Sect. of Public Education at Quebec, the Hon. Mr. Le Brunaye, on the subject of the school on my reserve, which bears the note "excellent" everywhere, which I hope will please the officers of the Department who devote themselves to the development and instruction among the Indians.

I have, &c.,

A. Tessier,
I.A.
